loans.name: Penina

texts.en: Penina is married with children and lives in the village of Vailoa-uta.  Penina’s family depends on her as the sole income earner.  Penina is seeking a loan to enhance her small business, through which she is able to cover the expenses of her family.  She operates a flea market stall and caters to the tourist market selling Samoan decorative arts and handicrafts, traditional jewelry, and traditional island clothes.  Penina hopes to draw more customers by increasing the quality and supply of her goods and so will use loan funds to purchase more and better materials to stock her flea market stall.

loans.use: Purchase more materials to stock her flea market stall, e.g. tanoa, beads, necklaces, bracelets, leis

loans.name: Alim

texts.en: Alim P. owns a cellular phone and cellular phone accessories store in the small town of Khachmaz, located on the Northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Alim would like to increase his inventory of cell phones and cell phone accessories in order to keep up with the demand of the growing cell phone market here in Azerbaijan.

loans.use: To increase inventory of cell phones and cell phone accessories

loans.name: Sadiq

texts.en: Sadiq has 6 years of experience in trade. He started receiving loans in July, 2005. He was one the first entrepreneurs in his town that received loans from MicroInvest and he has been advising the same to others since then. The loans he has been receiving were small in size because his business turnover is not very speedy. Sadiq is a handicapped person, but he has an active lifestyle.  He travels to Uzbekistan to buy the goods himself. His current business site is in open-air market and he would like to change it. Therefore he needs funds for new shelves and rent payment for the first three months.

loans.use: Change his business site

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Taumaia

texts.en: Taumaia and her husband would not be able to cover the expenses of their large family of eight without the income Taumaia earns from running a local food stall in the Samoan village of Faleula.  Taumaia’s cordial drinks and pork sandwiches are top sellers in the neighborhood.  A loan will help Taumaia purchase additional food supplies (specifically purified water, cordials, pork buns) for her stall and increase the variety of choices and the food quality that she is able to offer her local customers.  Taumaia is passionate about growing her business and using the income to make improvements to her family’s living quarters.

loans.use: Buy food supplies for her food stall

loans.name: Mekke

texts.en: Mekke N. (employee pictured) owns a small clothing stand at the local bazaar in the small town of Khachmaz located on the Northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Mekke is looking for funding so that she can increase the quantity and variety of her inventory so that she can attract more customers to her stand.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and variety of her inventory.

loans.name: Faamata

texts.en: Faamata joined the SPBD Program in 2004, and she was elected Secretary of SPBD’s Siuniu Center.  Most of her family moved to New Zealand, and Faamata and her husband struggle to survive and support their four children in Samoa without relying on remittances.  Three years ago, Faamata applied for her first loan of ST 750 (approximately USD 300), and she used that money to buy chemicals, fertilizers and other supplies for the taro plantation that she keeps near her house.  Faamata’s taro farm represents the main source of income for her family.  Having repaid her initial loans and raised her family’s living standard with the income from the expanded taro plantation, Faamata is committed to continuing to invest in her business.  Faamata is seeking an additional SPBD loan for two purposes:  to buy supplies and equipment for the taro farm and to make necessary repairs to the floor of her house.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies and equipment and make home improvements

loans.name: Serdar

texts.en: Serdar S. (employee pictured) owns a small clothing stand at the local bazzar in the small town of Khachmaz located on the Northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Serdar would like to invest in increasing his inventory so that she can continue to compete with the other clothing shops in the community.

loans.use: To purchase newer varieties of clothing for his stand

loans.name: Pau

texts.en: Pau is a married mother of five grown children.  While one of her children has found employment, the other four remain unemployed.  Her family largely relied on remittances from relatives in New Zealand and Australia, but a few years ago, Pau was determined to stop relying on remittances.  She became a member of SPBD and used her first loan to start up her business making banana chips.  Having fully repaid her first loan and established her business, she used a second loan to make necessary improvements to her home.  Now with the second loan repaid in full and on time, Pau is seeking a third loan to make an additional investment in her business.  With these funds, she hopes to ensure a more consistent, daily supply of her banana chips to her buyers and thereby increase her sales.

loans.use: Buy supplies for making banana chips

loans.name: Ayaz

texts.en: Ayaz M. owns a fruit and vegetable stand at the local bazaar in the small town of Khachmaz, located on the Northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Ayaz would like to invest in increasing the quantity and variety of his inventory in order to attract more customers to his stand. He wants to remain competitive with the other local fruit and vegetable stands in the community.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and variety of his inventory.

loans.name: Alofa

texts.en: Alofa exclaims, “I love being a business woman – what a blessing and privilege. Not just being a mother of four but a shop-keeper!  I hope all business women feel the same way!”  After Alofa’s husband died, she needed to support her four children on her own.  In dire need, Alofa built up the courage to apply for an SPBD loan to open a small village store.  Now she is able to earn enough to meet the basic needs of her family and has earned the pride and self-satisfaction of being a successful entrepreneur.  Having repaid her first loan, Alofa is applying for an additional loan to upgrade her shop and enhance her product line.  A loan to Alofa will ensure that she can continue to keep her store fully stocked and in good condition so that she can provide food, clothing, shelter and an education for her four children.

loans.use: Stock and upgrade her shop

loans.name: Sadat

texts.en: Sadat M. (employee pictured) owns a small stand at the local bazaar in the small town of Khachmaz, located in the Northeastern part of Azerbaijan. Sadat sells many different items at his stand: hair brushes, belts, radios, bags, clocks, toys and more. He would like to increase the quantity and variety of his inventory to include more items that people use in their daily lives in order to increase his daily sales.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and variety of his inventory.

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Married with four children, Malia is the breadwinner in her family.  She joined the SPBD in order to apply for a loan to support the two-acre taro plantation she tends.  Malia’s taro harvest is the only source of income for her family, and thus, she is passionate about investing in her field and improving her crop yields.  In a good week, Malia is able to generate income of ST 400 (approximately USD 150) by selling her taro in the local village markets.  Malia is also passionate about growing her savings account.  She deposits approximately ST 50 per week (approximately USD 20) into her savings account to ensure that her children’s school fees can be paid and home repairs can be made.

loans.use: Buy equipment and supplies for her taro farm

loans.name: Fusi

texts.en: Fusi is a married mother of three children.  Her small business is the sole source of income for her family.  By selling flavoured “ice cakes” and occasionally traditional hand-woven mats, she is currently able to bring in ST 150 – 200 per week (approximately USD 60 – 75).  However, this meagre income barely covers the expenses of her family, and Fusi strives to increase her family’s standard of living yet further.  With a loan Fusi can increase her supply of ice cakes to meet the demand in her village as well as enhance her product line by providing more flavours.  Additional income would go to ensuring that she can consistently provide the basic necessities for her family – food, shelter and clothing.

loans.use: Buy supplies for making “ice cakes”, e.g. cordials, sugar, packages

loans.name: Taavaoga

texts.en: Ta’avaoga is a 25-year old, single woman living in a small Samoan village.  Prior to joining SPBD in 2004, she had no job.  She applied for her first loan of ST 750 (approximately USD 300) to open a small grocery store in her village.  Now Ta’avaoga is the primary breadwinner for her family, which includes her parents and seven brothers.  She is confident that she can further grow her business to service the local village’s needs and increase her family’s standard of living.  To this end, Ta’avaoga is applying for another SPBD loan to expand her product line and ensure the basic necessities are consistently available in her store for the local villagers.

loans.use: Purchase additional goods to stock her grocery store

loans.name: Nafesa

texts.en: Nafesa D/O G. A. was born in 1962 and lives in District 7 of Kabul City. She is married and helps her husband financially with her Bead Working business. When she first started her business she lacked the money to buy all the material she needed, but she worked hard and made good quality clothes and sold them in the market. Her first loan was used to buy beads and fabric to produce more clothes to sell. She is ready to take another loan in order to purchase more beads and fabrics which will enable her to produce more clothes and do more business in the market.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and beads

loans.name: Faataumamate

texts.en: Faataumamate is a 47-year old woman with seven children to support.  Her husband’s meager income cannot cover the expenses for this large family, and Faataumamate’s farm is critical to providing for the education of her children.  She can earn usually earn ST 200 – 400 (approximately USD 115 – 150) a week by selling the taro that she raises at the local market, but Faataumate feels that she could do more if she could access the necessary funds to grow her farm.  To expand her farm, Faataumamate wants to buy some fertilizer to increase the yield of her taro farm as well as to buy some beef cattle to raise.

loans.use: Agricultural supplies

loans.name: Masinafou

texts.en: Masinafou is 33 years old and is married with three children.  Her husband's meager income is not enough to support their family and cover their children’s educational expenses. Masinafou has turned to the SPBD program to request a loan to start a bakery business.  She has the agreement of school officials to act as caterer for her local village’s primary school and the one in a nearby village.  Now she just needs the funds to purchase bulk supplies and a few small pieces of equipment to get started.  Masinafou is confident that she can use a loan to launch a successful business and become the primary breadwinner in her family

loans.use: Purchase cooking ingredients and equipment

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana is 52 years old, married and has four children.  Ana is passionate about providing for the education of her children. She joined SPBD two years ago and has used several previous loans to upgrade her small village store.  Through these upgrades to the building structure and an expansion in product line, Ana has been able to earn enough income to fund the college expenses of two of her children.  She is very proud that she is able to send her children to the National University of Samoa.  The expansion of Ana’s store is not yet complete, however, and she is seeking additional funds to make further upgrades.  She is confident that there is enough demand in her village for a further enhanced product line.

loans.use: Purchase additional goods for her grocery shop

loans.name: Kalameli

texts.en: Kalameli is a 70-year old widow with eleven children.  She had always relied on the income of her husband, but when he died, she was left with only three cows and no savings.  Kalameli then decided to join SPBD, and she used the loan funds to start up a small grocery shop in her village.  The launch of the store has been successful, and Kalameli, who had never before made her own money, can now support herself and provide for the basic necessities of many members of her family.  Kalameli recognizes the value of her business and  wants to continue to reinvest in it.  She is seeking an additional loan in order to expand the product line that she is able to offer her local customers.

loans.use: Expand her shop activities

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira, D/O G. A., was born in 1964. She is married and lives in District 7 of Kabul city. She has a doll Mmaking business and through that she helps her family financially. She is in her first loan cycle and though this loan she has purchased more fabrics, wood, and beads to make more dolls and sell them at the market.

During the wars her family really suffered financially because there was less chance for women to study and work and just her husband was working at that time. As a result her children weren't able to go to school. But after the wars she started to work beside her husband and now their financial situation has somehow improved and she is able to send her children to school again. She is happy with the loan process and wants to take more loans in the future.

loans.use: Buying plastic, fabrics, wood, beads, etc.

loans.name: Itagia

texts.en: Itagia is a 49-year old, married woman with eight children.  She applied for her first loan of ST 800 (approximately USD 300) in order to start a taro farm.  This taro farm has allowed her family to cover their basic expenses and is now their major income source.  Itagia is convinced that she can do yet more to raise her family’s standard of living.  She is enthusiastic about the SPBD program given the results she has seen thus far from her hard work.  She is now seeking additional funds to buy some basic time-saving, yield-improving supplies to help her on the farm (e.g. a wheelbarrow and some fertilizer)

loans.use: Agricultural supplies

loans.name: Selega

texts.en: Selega is 43 years old, married and has one child.  As the main income earner for her immediate and extended family, she applied for a loan from SPBD several years ago.  She used the initial and subsequent loans to purchase fishing nets and set up her taro plantation.  Now with both agricultural projects running, she can earn up to ST 300 (approximately USD 115) a week, which is enough to provide the basic necessities for her family.  But Selega is committed to raising her family’s standard of living further and she seeks an additional loan to buy fungicides to increase her taro yield and to make some necessary repairs to her fishing equipment.

loans.use: Purchase fungicides and repair her fishing equipment

loans.name: Mena

texts.en: Mena, who born in 1973, is a mother of 3 children. She is living in district 7 Kabul, Afghanistan. She has a clay pan business with 5 years experience. She makes these items in her house. After completing the process her husband sells in the bazaar especially to the tourists and foreigners buying these materials. In the summer, she makes lots of clay pots with new designs and good quality and then she sells them where people come for holiday and sightseeing. To support her family financially, she prefers this business, so therefore she took a loan to buy more materials for her shop.

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase two cows and inputs for his farming business

loans.name: Asoleaga

texts.en:
Asoleaga is a 23-year old, single female from the small Samoan village of Seesee. Asoleaga attended a local college and graduated with honors. Additionally, she received an award for being the top student in her Home Economics class, where she learned many useful things, like sewing and cooking.

Upon graduation, Asoleaga wanted to start her own restaurant, but the start-up expenses were too high. She joined the SPBD program in order to finance the start-up of a smaller venture, a food stall that caters to the locals. Asoleaga feels like the success of her small food stall is getting her closer to her goal of opening a full restaurant. She is gaining confidence and learning a lot about how to manage a business. A loan to Asoleaga, coupled with her hard work and savings, will get her even closer to meeting her goal.

loans.use: Buy more cooking supplies and ingredients

loans.name: Maimoana

texts.en:
Maimoana lives in the small Samoan village of Vaimoso. She runs the only shop in her area and provides necessary food and goods for local villagers. Maimoana has used previous SPBD loans to finance the growth of her village store. The success of her business is tangible and has greatly contributed to enhancing the lives of her family.

Maimoana’s husband is a wage earner at one of the Samoan shipping companies, and with their dual income, they have been able to provide a good education for each of their five children. Three of their children are now grown and have been able to secure good jobs, and the other two remain in school. Additionally, Maimoana’s entrepreneurial success has allowed her family to begin construction of a brick house, which represents a big step up in her family’s living conditions. Providing an additional loan to Maimoana will enable her to extend her shop still further, contributing to continued financial success for her and her family.

loans.use: Re-stock her village shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase livestock and build a cattle shed for his dairy farming business

loans.name: Tuavale

texts.en:
Tuavale is married with two sons, ages nine and eleven. Her husband is a fisherman. While Tuavale used to be employed by a manufacturing plant, she found her wages coupled with her husband’s income could not support her family’s needs and specifically, her sons’ education.

In need of growing their income, Tuavale’s entrepreneurial spirit led her to leave her manufacturing job and use a start-up loan from SPBD to launch her own business. Tuavale has a passion for designing fabric prints and used the loan funds to buy the fabric and materials to start a fabric design and printing business. Now with Tuavale’s business her family has a decent income. She turns a healthy profit and is seeking an additional loan to invest further in her business. She will use the loan to buy more fabric paints and the materials for carving more designs. She sells these printed fabrics to local seamstresses and shops, and they are used for making the dresses that are popular with Samoan women.

loans.use: Buy more fabric paints and carved designs for printing

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is married with five children. Prior to opening her small village store, neither Rosa nor her husband had work. Neither of them graduated from secondary school, and this has made Rosa passionate about ensuring that each of her five children remain in school so that they can secure good jobs after graduation. So far, her children have done well in school but saving enough for their school fees and supplies is nearly impossible for her and her husband.

Rosa took out an initial loan from SPBD in order to start up a small village store in her home. Rosa’s house is open, with no walls or windows and so it is very difficult to pack and unpack the goods everyday to fill the makeshift shelves. Having paid back the first loan, Rosa is requesting additional loan funds in order to re-stock her shop and build walls at the corner of her house where she is selling. This will enable her to ensure the store goods remain dry and can be locked up to prevent theft. Supporting Rosa with a loan will help her make a key enhancement to her business and help her earn the income to ensure she can continue to fund her children’s education.

loans.use: Re-stock her store and repair her home / shop

loans.name: Tagiilima

texts.en:
Tagiilima is a 45-year old married mother of eight children. While three of her grown children emigrated to New Zealand to seek better employment, the remaining five are young and are still with Tagiilima.

Tagiilima and her husband are fishermen and rely on their fishing expeditions as their sole source of income to provide for their family and finance their children’s education. With the help of an SPBD loan, they have been able to set up a small shop to sell their fishing catch and a few other goods. With the first loan fully repaid, Tagiilima is seeking an additional loan to buy fishing gears and upgrade their fishing nets. Someday, Tagiilima hopes that they can save enough money to expand their shop into a large village store and rely less on their daily catch to cover the expenses of their large family.

loans.use: Buy fishing gears and other equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase building materials and hire laborers for his rental houses business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy haircare products and equipments for his salon business

loans.name: Shukria

texts.en:
Shukria's son (pictured) is 18 and has a gas shop. Shukria manages the cash for the shop. She has five children, and three of them work in the gas shop. She will use the loan to expand her son's business to make more money to bring positive changes to the the business and her life.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the son of the female entrepreneur, Shukria. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Shukria and her son (pictured) would like to buy more gas for their gas store

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Sek L. is 41 years old and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia with her husband and five children.  Her husband is a construction worker and typically earns $5.00 per day.  One of her children works at a garment factory and earns about $90 per month.  Another is a blacksmith in the village.  L. hopes to use this loan to expand her business, growing morning glory vegetables.  In the future, she would like to build a house to rent as another source of income.  She hopes that her business will generate enough money so that she can send her children to university.

loans.use: To buy equipment to grow morning glory vegetables and to a buy boat to harvest vegetables

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Enock

texts.en:
Enock is married with three children. He lives in the Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam. The area is well known for residents' engaging themselves in animal keeping. Enock sells animal feed to these animal keepers. He buys by-products of maize, cotton, palm kernels, sunflowers and other cereals and packs them in bags of 20kgs to 50 kgs ready for resale.

Enock is planning to expand his business by stocking some other types of animal feeds which are professionally manufactured like broiler-mash and layer-mash for chickens. He also needs a bicycle which he will use to ferry products purchased by his customers to their premises as an after-sale service.

Enock also keeps layers of which his wife is in charge. He is planning to add the flock of these layers to supplement his income in order to meet family requirements as well as school fees for his children. To meet his expectation, Enock is in need of USD 750.

loans.use: Increase stock of animal feeds

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph lives in the Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam. He is married with six children. He is the owner of M. shop. He opened this shop five years ago after getting a loan from Akiba Commercial Bank (ACB). Since then his shop has been in good shape and attracts more customers. Recently two shops have been opened adjacent to him that threaten his market share. Joseph wants to maintain his market share by adding some items which his competitors do not have. This could be a competitive advantage to him. He is requesting a loan of USD 750.

loans.use: Increase stock of shop items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase computer accessories and hire two assistants for his computer repairs business

loans.name: Bibi Allah Gul

texts.en:
Bibi Allah Gul is a widow who lost her husband in the Taliban regime, and she has four childern. Bibi wants to get a loan to buy more material for her sons' shop (pictured) to expand their business selling oil and repairing bicycles so they can earn more profit.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile are the sons of the female entrepreneur, Bibi. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Bibi would like to buy the materials needed to repair bicycles and to buy oil to re-sell

loans.name: Mlamua

texts.en:
Mlamua lives in Mbagala in Dar es Salaam. He is married with three children. He also takes care of his brother's three kids. His brother died last year in a car accident. He is self-employed and owns a small shop near his residence. The shop sells different consumable items, mainly food items, which have high demand, especially rice and maize flour. The shop provides him with an opportunity to raise his children.

He would like to expand his business so that he can meet costs of educating his children. The shop employs himself and his wife. To expand his business he needs a US$ 1000

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Wangaeli

texts.en:
S. is married with four children. He lives in the Kiwalani area in Dar es Salaam. He owns a shop near his residence. The shop provides him with the income to raise the family. He sells different items in his shop, like detergents, sugar, salt, soap, coffee, tea and cold drinks.

He recently realized high demand for sewing and tailoring supplies. With his savings, he managed to stock a few of these sewing materials. He cannot meet the demand for these items due to insufficient working capital. He is in need of additional capital of USD 1000 to run this new line of business effectively and add to his stock of existing items.

loans.use: To add a new line of business

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina has five children and she wants to get a loan for her son's shop to buy more fuel and expand his business. She manages the cash for her son's store. By getting the loan she hopes to make her family's life better.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the son of the female entrepreneur, Sakina. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Sakina would like to buy more gas/petrol to sell in her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his weighing equipment maintenance business

loans.name: Mahshooqa

texts.en:
Mahshooqa is a married woman with four children who is asking for a loan for her husband. She manages the cash for their bicycle repair shop and takes part in cleaning the bicycle parts. They work hard to make their life better. They want to expand their business by getting a loan.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of the female entrepreneur, Mahshooqa. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Mahshooqa would like to buy more parts to repair bicylces

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for his shoe-making business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his meat selling business

loans.name: Merwareed

texts.en:
Merwareed is 30 years old. She is married and has four children. She has 7 years experince in keeping cattle. Every year she has bought sheep and has been raising the sheeps' and cows' offspring. She has a very good business selling the sheep's wool and from their milk she makes cheese, butter, and yogurt and sells it to the market. She is asking for a loan to expand her business and make more money.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the entrepreneur, Merwareed. She is facing away from the camera because in Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet.

loans.use: Merwareed would like to buy more sheep for her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his horticulture and trading business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bicycle parts for his repairs business

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina is 29 years old. She is maried and has four children. She has 8 years experience in tailoring. She sews clothes for her neigborhood. Sakina wants to get a loan to buy fabric and other required material so she can make different types of clothes and sell them to the bazzar. She is a hard working woman and she wants to expand her business and make her family's life better.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is Sakina facing away from the camera. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet.

loans.use: Sakina would like to buy more fabric, thread and sewing material for her tailoring business

loans.name: Mohtrama

texts.en: Mohtrama is 38 lives in district 6 Kabul in a household of four. He has a burger shop where he sells burgers, chips, eggs and soft drinks. He believes in the summer people want more soft drinks, so he took a loan to buy more. He would like another loan to buy a refrigerator for his shop and rebuild his shop with a new design.

loans.use: Mohtrama would like to buy a refrigerator for his burger shop and help rebuild it

loans.name: Mir Mohammad Afzal

texts.en: Mir is 45 years old. He has 10 years experience in selling food items. He is married and has four children. He wants to get a loan to buy more food items for his shop and expand his business. He is living in a rental house and he wishes to make more money so he can buy a nice house for his family.

loans.use: Mir would like to buy more food items for his shop to expand his business

loans.name: Hameeda

texts.en:
Hameeda is 24 and the mother of two small children. They live in Kabul City. Hameeda took this loan for her husband to buy construction supplies and materials for his shop to increase his business. During the war she faced lots of difficulties when she took over for her husband to help his family financially. Since her husband works outside of the city, she hopes to complete this loan cycle so she can take another loan for her own business.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of the female entrepreneur, Hameeda. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Hameeda would like to buy glass and supplies for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To diversify his farming business by purchasing a cow

loans.name: Sayed Omer

texts.en: S. is 18 years old. He makes bolani which is a famous Afghan food. He has 4 years experience making bolani. His father is very sick and cannot work. So he is working hard to run his family of six. He is asking for a loan to expand his business to get supplies to prepare more bolani and hire some students to make them.

loans.use: Sayed would like to buy flour, leeks and potatoes as well as gas for his bolani stand

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Dorah would like to buy a high breed dairy cow

loans.name: Abbasov

texts.en: A. is Internally Displace Person from the Aremenian-occupied Fizuli region of Azerbaijan. He and his family of his wife and four children were relocated to Beylagan region. As they were traditionally engaged in cattle breeding, he started this business in Beylagan since 2003. At that time he borrowed $400 from Normicro Beylagan branch to buy calves. Later he borrowed $600, $900 and finally $1000. He has good repayment history. NOw he applies for $1200 to buy more cows and expand the business.

loans.use: To buy two more cows

loans.name: Marzia

texts.en:
Marzia is 22 years old. She lives in Kabul City with nine family members. She took a loan for her brother who has a general store to buy more items for the shop. She knows how to tailor but due to family problems she cannot work outside, so she sews her neighbors' clothes.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the brother of the female entrepreneur, Marzia. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Marzia would like to buy more goods for her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy raw materials for his carpentry business

loans.name: Mutabar

texts.en:
Mutabar is 35 years old. She is married and has two sons. Her family was never rich and Mutabar could not get a good education and as a result could not get a well-paid job. Her husband was the only bread-winner but several years ago he lost his job.

Mutabar had a small table by her house where she sold fried sunflower seeds. She bought raw seeds, fried them and sold them by her house. When she started receiving loans she started at $15. Over time she increased the loan amount and her next loan will be $100. By using her next loan she would like to add other small goods in her sales, like matches, candy and others.

loans.use: Business expansion

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Joyce intends to buy the seed and seedlings, fertilizers and plastic boxes to assist her deliver the produce to the market

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to expand business by buying more vegetables and cereal crops in bulk to cater for times before harvest time

loans.name: Kimyu

texts.en:
Kimyu is married. She brings her goods from Khujand and Istaravshan which is about a 1-2 hours drive from her town. She makes this trip once a week.

Kimyu says that if she had more money she could have bought more goods on each trip and save time and money for the road.

She has been receiving loans starting 2003. Her first loan was $80. When she learned that she needs to form a group of entrepreneurs like herself for a solidarity group guarantee, she asked her friends from the same market to join her and they started receiving loans together. Since then, her business has developed dramatically. Now she sells not only female clothes, but added men's and children's clothes. Since Kimyu works in open-air market, she dreams of having her own shop. The next loan will be used for a trip to the wholesale market.

loans.use: Business expansion

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and prepare his land for commercial farming

loans.name: Babayev

texts.en: A. is local resident of Beylagan region. He is 59 years old. He is engaged in cattle breeding in his house yard. He has been doing this business since 2002 and it is only source of earning income for the living. When he started the business he applied for loans to Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed $600 to buy calves. He breeds them and later he sells or delivers them to butchery shops. Now he needs $1200 to buy more cows and expand the business.

loans.use: To buy two more cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mary would like to buy a water tank and another dairy cow

loans.name: Malika

texts.en:
Malika has many years of experience in trade. At the beginning, she was helping her father and later separated her own business. She was very successful in her business. She is sure that her success is in variety of goods that she sells.

Mastchoh is small town with a small number of customers, so selling only one type of goods is not very profitable. When she started working in the market she used to sell only female clothes, then added men’s and kids' clothes. She brings her goods from Khujand and Istaravshan weekly. Over time she added clocks, perfume and gifts in her assortment. With her last loan she also added various toys.

loans.use: Adding assortment of toys

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam is 30 years old. She took a loan for her husband who has a vegetable and grocery shop in the market. She studied up to high school, but because of the war she could not complete her education. She also works in her own house sewing neighbor’s clothes and she is very happy that this process is available for poor people.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of the female entrepreneur, Maryam. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Maryam would like to buy more vegetables for her grocery shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Jalilova

texts.en: Z. is a resident of Beylagan town. She is 45 years old and has three children. She owns a shop in the town center where she sells household items of various usees. She has been doing this business since 2002. When she started $she applied to Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed 300 to buy inventory. She increased the sales and applied for more loans; $600, $800 and $1000. Now she needs $1200 to increase the inventory in the shop.

loans.use: To increase the number of inventories

loans.name: Sanoat

texts.en:
Sanoat used to be a labor migrant in Russia. It was very difficult for her to leave her children and work in Russia, coming home only for couple of months per year. Therefore, as soon as she made enough money to start her own business, she did so.

Sanoat started her trade at the open-air market with a place 1 meter wide. She considered this place not busy and actively visited by customers, so her first goal was to afford renting better place in the market. She heard about MicroInvest 3 years ago and started receiving loans there. After receiving several loans she could afford to change her place in the market. At the beginning she had only $300 in her turnover and now has over $1200. She will use her next loan for the trip to the wholesale market to buy new seasonal goods.

loans.use: Trip to wholesale market

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to buy in bulk, flour, salt, match boxes, laundry detergents and cereals in bulk for her retail shop

loans.name: Eyvazov

texts.en:
Parvis is a 26 year-old resident of Beylagan town. In 2006 he started the business of butchery and he rents a shop near marketplace. In 2006 he applied to Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed his first loan amounting to $750. He repaired the shop and bought sheep to slaughter. He wants to improve the quality of service and wants to buy a counter-refrigerator.
He is applying for $900 as his second loan.

loans.use: To buy a counter-refrigerator

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sylvia would like to buy laundry detergents, soft drinks, cereals, flour, beverages and animal feeds in bulk for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to buy a water tank

loans.name: Deba

texts.en:
Deba is 21 and single. She lives with her family of six in district 3 of Kabul City. She took a loan for her brother to buy parts for his bicycle shop. Her brother has 3 years experience repairing bicycles and motor bikes but due to lack of materials and money he left the motor bike repairing. He repairs two or three bicycles in a day and sometimes repairs the tires and tubes as well.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the brother of the female entrepreneur, Deba. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Deba would like to buy bicycle parts for her brother's bicycle repair shop

loans.name: Ismayilova

texts.en: F. is 54 year-old resident of Beylagan town. She owns a shop where she sells food stuffs. In 2004 she applied to Normicro Beylagan branch for the first time and borrowed $300. She used the loan to increase the stock of goods in the shop. Increasing the volume of sales, she applied for subsequent loans in the amounts of $400 and $500. Successfully paying back the loans, now she applies for the next loan in amount of $700 to expand the business more.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair his lorry for commercial transportation

loans.name: Samadhon

texts.en:
Samadhon has a University degree from Dushanbe Medical Institute. He works as a dentist in the village called Kizil-pilol, of Isfara district. At the beginning his main income from his work as a dentist was enough to feed his family. Over time the family was growing and now Samadhon supports his wife, who doesn’t work, and four children.

From his childhood he has known how to take care of cows and decided to earn money by keeping livestock in his yard. His family helps him in this. When he is at work, his children and his wife take care of the cows and feed them. When he received his first loan he bought a bull-calf and fodder. Since then he bought several bulls and sold the ones that were big enough to sell at a good price. He would like to use his next loan for repairs of the cow-shed in his yard.

loans.use: Repairs of cow-shed

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Mosompa intends to buy three steers

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en: Yashar is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli region. He and his family were relocated to Beylagan region. After many hardships of being an IDP, he started a business and built a small booth where he is engaged in butchery. He has been doing this business since 2003. He applied to Normicro Beylagan branch for the first time in 2003 and borrowed $300 to buy sheep and slaughter them. Then he borrowed three more loans to develop the business. Now he needs $500 to buy ten sheep.

loans.use: To buy ten sheep

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is very hard working and focused. She bought 5 steers which were fattened and sold in three months' time. She supplements the feeds with fodder crops. Being a Maasai, she has fought against all odds to educate her girl. (Early marriage that is part of the Maasai Culture has been a hindrance to educating the girl child.)

Her plan is to buy small steers for fattening. She will sell the ready steers to the Kenya Meat Commission. She needs a loan of USD 600 to add three more steers in order to boost her income to pay school fees and repay her loan. She will pay her loan in monthly installments.

loans.use: Patricia would like to buy three steers

loans.name: Shamila

texts.en:
Shamila lives in District 3 of Kabul City and is married. She has taken the loan for her son who runs a tailoring shop. At the start of her son's business they had few materials for tailoring, so they had few customers. It was difficult for them to keep going with their shop because they had to use the income from the shop to pay its rent. Then Shamila heard about Small Loans and she decided to start taking loans. Shamila is now in her first loan cycle and with this loan amount she would like to purchase more fabric in order to make more clothes and a machine with which her son can make clothes faster. She is pleased with the loan procedure because with the amount not only can they expand their business but they can also fulfill their daily expenses.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the son of the female entrepreneur, Shamila. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Shamila would like to buy fabric, needles, thread, etc. and a machine for her tailoring business

loans.name: Maharram

texts.en: Maharram is the resident of Beylagan town. He is 54 years old. He has a small shop hear his house. He built this shop in 2002 and sells food and various items of household use. He is an old client of Normicro Beylagan branch. He borrowed his first loan in 2003 in amount of $300. Later he borrowed $600, $900 and $1000. He is makes payments on time and has a good repayment history. Now he applies for the next loan in amount of $1200 to buy more items to be sold in his shop.

loans.use: To increase the volume of sales

loans.name: Mohammad Azem

texts.en: Mohammad Azem is 40 years old and lives with his family of eight in Kabul City. He sells fuel, gas, petrol, diesel and mobile and he has a small shop near the road where he can sell lots of fuel - more than other pump stations. He wants to buy a tank of fuel for his business so he can sell to other shops.

loans.use: Mohammed would like to buy more fuel for his fuel store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Grace would like to buy three steers

loans.name: Gabil

texts.en: Gabil is a 27 year-old local resident. He is married and has two children. He is engaged in cattle breeding and selling. He has been doing this business since 2004 and now has three cows. At first he borrowed $600 from Normicro Beylagan branch to buy livestock. His subsequent loans were $900 and $1000. The business is now developing. He needs $1200 to buy four calves and increase his income.

loans.use: To buy four calves

loans.name: Jensiama

texts.en: Ohenewa is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She has benefited from its products for several years. She wants to expand her business. She sells Ghanaian Kentey cloth. She is seeking a loan of $950.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida is 39 and lives in District 13 of Kabul City. She is a widow and runs a hairdressing salon. Up until the time of her husband's death, their life was normal but after she lost her husband during the war, life got really difficult for her. She didn't have any other choice except to start her own business. Hamida started by collecting some money from her relatives in order to start her own business but due to lack of money she faced lots of problems. After hearing about the loan process she took a loan and started to expand her business. Hamida has now finished 2 cycles of loans and now she wants to take the 3rd cycle to buy more materials for her salon in order to have more customers and earn enough income.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the entrepreneur, Hamida. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman's face on the Internet.

loans.use: Hamida would like to buy more makeup and hair supplies to sell at her hair salon

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia has benefited from the TEACH product of Kraban Support Foundation. She is a hairdresser and owns a salon. She needs a loan of $800.00 from Kiva to expand her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Taleh

texts.en: Taleh is an Internally Displace Person from the Armenian-occupied Khojavand region of Azerbaijan. When his family was relocated, he was a boy. Now he is 19 years old. His family faced many hardships. Now Taleh wants to contribute to the family income. He rented a room where he has only one TV and game device. Many children come to play games. Now he wants to buy two more computers to attract more people to his game cafe and also provide Internet services. This is his first loan and he wants $300.

loans.use: To buy two computers

loans.name: Sadeqa

texts.en:
Sadeqa is 52 and the mother of three children. She took a loan for her youngest son who has a bicycle repair shop near the road. She can't work outside because she has a physical problem, so she took the loan for her son to buy bicycle parts. During the day, she visits her son and sometimes she works with him together at home fixing the bicycles. She hopes to complete the loan and buy a tailoring machine to help her son and sew clothes for their neighbors.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the son of the female entrepreneur, Sadeqa. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Sadeqa would like to buy bicycle parts for her repair shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use:
Valley Arcade Hub Salon.
Loan usage: Marble would like to buy three hair-driers and chemicals for her salon

loans.name: Bernice

texts.en: Bernice sells a local meal "fante kenkey" in the evening in her community. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She is  seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jiona would like to buy three hair-driers and chemicals

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina lives in Katapo, Pokuase, Ghana. She sells salt in bags to her clients. She is an active client of Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $800.00.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ismat

texts.en: Ismat has been keeping livestock since his childhood.  He learned how to do it from his father. He grew up in a big family and now has a big family on his own. He is married and has 5 children. Both his wife and he work on a collective farm. There they work on the fields growing cotton and other agricultural products. When Ismat started keeping livestock independently from his father, he started with only one sheep. Currently he has 5 cows, 2 bulls, 2 sheep and 6 chickens. He needs $800 for repairs of the cow-shed and its expansion.

loans.use: Repairs of cow-shed

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia sells provisions. She has attended several training programmes by Kraban Support Foundation for women in trade on simple record-keeping and business management. She wants a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to enable her to open a shop.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Eunice would like to buy 4 bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Susan would like to buy 4 bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Parascovia

texts.en:
Parascovia is a very strong-willed person, someone who has found ways of overcoming the problems and obstacles with which she has been confronted in her life. She comes from a family of farmers and as a young person tried in many ways to advance herself and to reach for a better life. After graduating from the high school in her region, she entered the university in the nearby city of Cahul, but having had limited financial support from her parents she was unable to finish her studies.

She began working as a sales person at the outdoor market as an employee of a business owner. The income which she was receiving was very small and was enough only to meet the most basic needs. Two years ago she decided to try something else and applied for a permit to open a small business, rented a place in the market and started to work independently. Parascovia sells clothing and currently her sales are going very well, due in large part to her keen sense for what customers want and her willingness to explore new fashions. She is requesting a loan to extend her operation, specifically to rent the spot next the one she currently uses and to purchase initial inventory.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience sells ladies' and gent's underwear. She is seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to enable her to  buy more goods for sale. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
Mahbuba is a mother of 4. She has 15 years of experience in trade. She has been receiving loans since July 2006. She is not only a member of the groups of entrepreneurs that receive loans, but also is responsible for timely collection of loan repayments.

Mahbuba has about $1800 in her turn over and makes $80 of profit per month. The market where she works is a wholesale market, and therefore she sells her goods not only retail but wholesale as well. She has constant clients. As she expands her business she hopes to conduct only wholesale trade. The goods she sells are mostly brought from China. She will use the next loan for new seasonal goods.

loans.use: New season goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Gladys would like to buy two standing driers, two blow driers and chemicals

loans.name: Sharifjon

texts.en: Sharifjon works together with his mother (his mother is on the photo). They started this business three years ago. From the beginning, they had a lack of capital to increase the assortment and quality of goods. Another goal that they have is opening a second business site. Currently they take turns working at the market. When Sharifjon is away to bring goods his mother conducts the retail trade. Their customers always ask for high quality goods and therefore they would like to change the source of goods. Sharifjon wants to go to the wholesale market in Kyrgystan.

loans.use: Better quality goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Antie Cecilia operates a drinking bar where she sells assorted drinks. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a Kiva loan of $850.00 to enable her expand. She is capable of paying back.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane would like to buy 3 bales of second-hand clothes and improve the business premises

loans.name: Tashbubu

texts.en:
Since olden times in Central Asia, carpet-making has been a famous activity. Production of carpets was considered to be the prestige profession and brought large income to workmen. Though nowadays when the market is filled with machine-made carpets, people still think that each house should have a handmade carpet.

Tashbubu, from childhood, sitting near her mother and grandmother saw how the carpets were woven. With time, it became her main profession. Nowadays everybody knows Tashbubu as an experienced master of her work. As her husband and her son are in Russia and there was a lack of money in the family, Tashbubu began to look for a source of funding of her activity and came to MicroInvest.

She received her first loan in the amount of $150, and she bought fleece and dye for her products and increase the amount of production. Her daughter and daughter-in-law help her in their business. Step-by-step, expanding her business, she bought mechanical equipment for fleece processing. The last loan, in the amount of $150, she fully spent for the purchase of raw material – fleece. With the new loan she wants to buy a new machine for weaving that will allow her to double the number of carpets produced.

loans.use: New equipment

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers for his commercial farming business.

loans.name: Manzurakhon

texts.en:
After B. Manzurakhon got divorced from her husband, she had to earn money on her own and decided to work at the market. Her children were old enough to work and they were searching for jobs as well. She started her business with a small amount and for some time she sold only male and child’s socks. Constantly putting aside small amounts, she increased the assortment and number of goods.

After she learned about MicroInvest, she came and received her first loan in size of $150 and fully spent it for high quality socks. It gave her the possibility to get new clients and keep her regular customers as well. She added children's clothes to her assortment as well. She started going to the wholesale market herself and, in this way, made additional profit. She needs a new loan to purchase new seasonal goods. She would like to receive $800. She also would like to change her trading place. In future, if everything goes according to her plan, she plans to rent a little shop.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Madam Regina sells fabrics from house to house in her community. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and very hardworking. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to enable her purchase more fabrics for sale.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ester

texts.en: Antie Ester sells tubers of yams in bulk to her customers. She buys from a very long distance away from her stand. She needs a loan of $950.00 from Kiva to enable her to buy more tubers for sale.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stocks for his farm products retail business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy metal and equipments for his blacksmith business

loans.name: Zinabu

texts.en: Zinabu sells charcoal to her customers in her community. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She has bennefited from the organizations product for several loan terms. She needs a loan of $800.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is the mother of three and loves taking care of her family, but doing so can be hard in Moldova. In order to provide better financial support for them, she quit working in local public administration and began her own small business. Despite difficulties in getting started Maria, persisted and for over four years now she has been the proud owner of a small clothing store at the market in Cahul. Anyone who knows her will say that by nature she is a hardworking and honest person, and that trust is part of what has helped her get loyal customers. She now has an income that, while modest, allows her to better meet the needs of her family. Maria would like a loan to fund the purchase of new goods in order to diversify her product offerings and thereby begin growing her business.

loans.use: Purchase of new products

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Antie Doris sells charcoal to her customers in her community. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She has benefited from the organizations product for several loan terms. She needs a loan of $800.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Antie D. sells various agricultural produce such as vegetables and tubers. She is seeking a loan of $800.00 from Kiva to enable her expand her business. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stocks for his vegetable and charcoal selling business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Antie Agie sells fabrics, children's wear and ladies' underwear. She is a beneficiary of Kraban Support Foundation's TEACH programme. She is seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva. She is hardworking and capable of paying back.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine andmore clothes stock for his tailoring business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Madam Mary sells fabrics, children's wear and ladies' underwear. She is a beneficiary of Kraban Support Foundation's TEACH programme. She is seeking a loan of $775.00 from Kiva. She is hardworking and capable of paying back.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Tina is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She lives in Katapo, POkuase, Ghana. She sells various items in her shop. She is seeking a Kiva loan of $800.00 to enable her expand her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Alexei

texts.en:
Alexei’s business is an agricultural one; specifically it involves growing vegetables, both in greenhouses and in open fields. He has been working in this area for four years, selling his harvest at the surrounding regional markets, and now wants to expand by starting production of three Dutch varieties of cucumber in addition to his other crops (radishes, watermelon, etc.).

He currently is working with greenhouse space of 370m2 and also with substantial outdoor space, some of which he would like to dedicate to the new, more profitable cucumbers. Alexei needs a loan to buy more vegetable seeds and construction materials for his greenhouses, including new plastic for covering, in order to begin with his expansion plan.

loans.use: Seed and construction material purchase

loans.name: Vadim

texts.en:
Vadim is married with two children. He is a technical school graduate. He works at a factory and also, together with his wife, owns a small business selling clothing for children. In business since 1999, they now have a couple of vending kiosks in the local market. Vadim is a high-achiever. He received his first loan from “Nadiya Ukraine” in 2003. Today he has repaid 12 loans with no defaults. His perseverance, clear vision and passion for business have led to the expansion of his small venture. Vadim has requested a loan for $1,000 to re-stock his inventory. He is planning to buy assorted clothing items for babies and children. Profits generated will be invested into further expansion of his business by purchasing a store which will increase his available retail space. Vadim believes his persistence and willpower are the keys to further successful growth in his trade. He knows that after he reaches this goal there will be new horizons, new challenges and new goals. He is ready to work hard to achieve true success while enjoying the journey along the way.

Вадим – одружений, в нього є двоє дітей. Після закінчення технікуму він працював на заводі. Потім вони з дружиною відкрили власну справу з продажу дитячого одягу. Вони займаються бізнесом з 1999 року, зараз в них вже дві торгові точки на одному з місцевих ринків. Вадим – вміє досягати поставленої мети. Першу позику від „Надії України” він отримав ще у 2003 році. Зараз він вже сплатив 12 попередніх позик без жодних прострочень. Наполегливість в роботі, чітке бачення та відданість власній справі сприяли розширенню його маленького бізнесу. Вадим просить про позику в 1000 доларів для того, щоб розширити асортимент товарів. Він хоче закупити більше одягу для малюків та дітей. Отриманий прибуток він планує вкласти в подальше розширення свого бізнесу. В майбутньому Вадим планує купити власну крамницю. Він вважає, що його наполегливість та сила волі – це ті ключі, які сприятимуть успішному зростанню його торгівлі. Вадим чудово розуміє, що після того, як він досягне своєї мети, в нього з’являться нові горизонти, нові випробування та нові цілі. Він готовий наполегливо працювати для того, щоб досягти успіху, отримуючи від цієї роботи величезну насолоду.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Mama Joyce sells electical parts in her shop. She has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for several years now. She has benefited a lot from its programme. She is seeking a loan of $825.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase two cows for his dairy farming business

loans.name: Lidiya

texts.en:
Lidiya, 57, is an enterprising business owner from Nikopol, located in south-central Ukraine. She runs several market kiosks where she sells a variety of men’s sports clothing and women’s clothing. Lidiya is known as a kind and hard working entrepreneur. She has a sharp business mind and has been able to gradually grow her operation into a successful enterprise. An outstanding client with Nadiya Ukraine, she has repaid a total of 17 loans to date. Lidiya has requested a loan that will add to her available working capital. Spring time leading into summer is a very busy time for market vendors as more customers take advantage of good weather and get out to shop. This additional capital will allow Lidiya to purchase necessary inventory so she can keep up with increased demand.

Лідії – 57 років. Вона – підприємець з Нікополя. Це місто розташоване в південній частині Центральної України. В неї декілька кіосків на місцевому ринку, вона торгує чоловічим спортивним та жіночим одягом. Усім відомо, що Лідія – привітна та працьовита. Її чіпкий розум та здатність мислити по-діловому допомогли їй досягти успіху в бізнесі. В Лідії чудова репутація в „Надії України”, вона вчасно сплатила усі 17 позик, які отримала в організації. Лідія просить про позику для того, щоб поповнити власний робочий капітал. Навесні та влітку в підприємців на ринку завжди дуже багато роботи, бо стає тепліше та багато покупців ходять по покупки. Додаткові кошти дозволять Лідії придбати необхідний інвентар та задовольнити зростаючий попит.

loans.use: Increase clothing inventory

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is a travelling merchant and takes her products (shirts, briefcases, cosmetics, etc) in the center of the country (other cities and smaller villages). She is 53 years old and has tree sons. She has more than 10 years of experience in her line of business and her work allows her to support her family. They live in the San Pedro district in the city of La Paz

Her sales are monthly and she takes her merchandise to the middle of the contry and delivery quantities.

She has been a client of Impro since September 2003. Her history with our organization has qualified her as a number 1 client, that is to say, with a Very Good recommenation. The total amount of requestest money will be put towrads the purchase of merchandise.

Her work experience and previous loans with Impro have allowed her access to ask for this loan. She already has the business experience necessary to wisely use this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Julia es comerciante viajera y lleva sus productos (poleras, carteras, cosméticos, etc.) al interior de país (otras ciudades y poblaciones pequeñas). Tiene 53 años y tres hijos, su experiencia en el rubro es de más de 10 años y su trabajo le permite sostener a su familia. Vive en la zona de San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz. Sus ventas son quincenales ya que lleva mercadería al interior del país y entrega por cantidad Es cliente de Impro, desde septiembre del año 2003. Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 1, es decir con cumplimiento Muy Bueno en el pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de mercadería. Su trabajo y antecedentes crediticios con Impro le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio. El cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Natalya runs a small business selling just about a little bit of everything. From telephones, tea pots and curling irons, to manicure sets, writing pens and women’s purses, she has been able to build her business by marketing those practical items that everybody can use. She operates from a little space at an indoor mall in Nikopol, Ukraine. Before starting her own business, Natalya worked as a salesperson for another store. This gave her valuable retailing experience which has benefited her as she has started her own enterprise. The assistance she has gained through loans from “Nadiya Ukraine” has also helped in her business development. Available funding has enabled her to maintain stability and growth. Natalya has requested a loan that will enable her to purchase additional inventory in bulk. She is always on the lookout for good prices from suppliers that will give her the ability to make a profit. By having an adequate amount of capital available, she can maximize her opportunities and continue developing a solid business.

В Наталії є власний невеличкий бізнес. Вона торгує усім потроху, починаючи з телефонів, чайників, прасок для волосся і закінчуючи манікюрними наборами, ручками та жіночими сумочками. Бізнес Наталії, розташований в торговому центрі в м Нікополь, розвивався завдяки торгівлі усіма цими практичними товарами. До того, як почати власний бізнес Наталія працювала продавцем в крамниці. Завдяки цій роботі вона отримала необхідний досвід роздрібної торгівлі, який знадобився їй, коли вона починала власну справу. Позики, які Наталія отримала від „Надії України”, також сприяли розвитку її бізнесу. Додаткові кошти дали їй можливість досягти стабільності та отримати додаткові прибутки. Наталія просить про позику, яка допоможе їй закупити товар оптом. Вона завжди уважно слідкує за цінами постачальників, низькі закупівельні ціни допомагають їй отримати прибуток від продажу. Отримавши необхідні додаткові кошти, Наталія зможе реалізувати власні можливості й надалі розвивати стабільний бізнес.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet sells fabrics from textile companies in her locality. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She is seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to enable her buy more fabrics to sell.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en:
Elmira is a young entrepreneur selling shoes and used clothing in the city of Berdyansk, as well as in the towns of Primorsk and Volodarskoye. Elmira owns a fully-stocked kiosk and matches her different markets with various quantities and qualities of clothing. Jeans clothing, shirts, pants and sportswear in all types and styles attract many customers to her business. Elmira is a very energetic and active person and faces her challenges with optimism. Married with a 4-year-old son, she knows how to balance work and family. Elmira is also a very responsible client with “Nadiya Ukraine”. She has received and repaid all loans with no defaults. She realizes that lending services have promoted stable growth for her business. Currently, Elmira has about $4,000 in inventory. Her monthly gross income amounts to $2,000, and her net profit is about $800. Elmira has requested a loan for $1,000 to invest in the further expansion of her trade. She believes that financial assistance will help boost her sales and generate additional profits which will help her spend more on her family and improve their living standard.

Ельміра – молодий підприємець, вона торгує взуттям та одягом секонд-хенд в Бердянську, а також в м. Приморськ та Володарське. В кіоску Ельміри завжди можна знайти широкий асортимент одягу, різних розмірів та якості. Різноманітний джинсовий одяг, сорочки, повсякденний та спортивний одяг приваблюють багато покупців. Ельміра – дуже енергійна та активна, вона з легкістю та оптимізмом долає будь-які випробування. Ельміра – одружена, в неї є чотирирічний син. Вона навчилася поєднувати роботу та родинні обов’язки. Ельміра – дуже відповідальна клієнтка „Надії України”. Вона отримала та сплатила усі позики без жодних прострочень. Вона розуміє, що кредитні послуги сприяли стабільному зростанню її бізнесу. Зараз в Ельміри в товар вкладено приблизно 4000 доларів. Її щомісячний дохід складає 2000 доларів, чистий прибуток становить 800 доларів. Ельміра просить про позику в 1000 доларів для того, щоб вкласти кошти в подальший розвиток торгівлі. Вона вважає, що фінансова допомога сприятиме росту продажів та допоможе їй отримати додатковий прибуток, а отже, витратити більше на власну родину та покращити їхній рівень життя.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is one of the most successful small business entrepreneurs in the city of Berdyansk. She is a real expert when it comes to the wholesale buying of quality kids' clothing inventory. Nataliya has been in business for 12 years. Currently, she has about $5,000 in inventory. Her monthly gross revenue amounts to $4,000 and her net profit is about $800 - $1,000 per month. Nataliya is an optimist. Her cheery attitude helps her succeed in business and establish good relationships with her clients. Nataliya has gone through many trials and challenges with her business such as lots of inventory rejects, slow-moving products, and unfavorable market policies. However, she has not only managed to keep her business sustainable but has also increased her sales. Nataliya would like to get a loan of $900 to purchase seasonal clothing for children from wholesalers. She is planning to buy a range of casual wear, sweaters and jackets for boys, as well as various fresh and trendy girls'-wear for the spring season. Nataliya believes that nice quality clothing that is stylish, practical, reasonably priced and easy to care for will make the shopping experience more enjoyable for many of her customers and will best serve their needs.

Наталія – одна з найуспішніших підприємців міста Бердянськ. Вона – справжній експерт з продажу якісного дитячого одягу. Наталія займається цим бізнесом вже 12 років. Зараз в неї приблизно 5000 доларів в товарі. Її щомісячний дохід складає приблизно 4000 доларів, чистий прибуток становить 800 - 1000 доларів на місяць. Наталія - оптиміст. Її привітне ставлення допомагає їй досягати успіху в бізнесі та встановлювати гарні стосунки з клієнтами. В роботі Наталії постійно виникають різні важкі питання: неякісний товар, одяг, який погано продається, невигідна ринкова політика. Однак, їй вдається не тільки підтримувати прибутковість свого бізнесу, але й постійно підвищувати обсяги продажів. Наталія хотіла б отримати позику в 900 доларів для того, щоб закупити сезонний одяг для дітей на оптовій базі. Вона планує придбати різноманітний повсякденний одяг, светри та куртки для хлопчиків, а також яскравий та модний одяг для маленьких дівчаток напередодні цього весняного сезону. Наталія вважає, що високоякісний, стильний та практичний одяг за помірними цінами, про який легко дбати, зробить покупки приємнішими та задовольнить потреби її покупців.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal clothing

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Mame Doris sells agri produce such as crates of eggs, vegetables, and cooking oils. She needs a Kiva loan of $750.00. She is hardworking and capable of paying back.

texts.en: Isha sells a local meal prepared from maize, "fante kenkey". She cooks in large quantities and supplies  her clients. She needs a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to enable her to cook more to supply her customers.

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.en:
Maria del Rosario has been operating a fast food business out of a small truck for 11 years. “I am a single mother, and one of my older children helps me in the business. I also have 3 young children. I earn my income selling food, and I need to purchase more food to be able to prepare different dishes and improve my sales. Also, I need tables and chairs where my customers can eat.” I am asking for $1,200.00 to buy ingredients, tables and chairs.

Translated from Spanish by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Maria del Rosario tiene su negocio de venta de comida rápida en un camioncito desde hace 11 años “Soy Mamá soltera y uno de mis hijos mayores me ayuda en el negocio, tengo 3 hijos más que son menores de edad, mis ingresos los obtengo de la venta de comida, necesito comprar más alimentos para preparar diferentes platillos y tener más ventas, así como mesas y sillas para que mis clientes coman” Solicito $ 1,200.00 dlls Para la compra de ingredientes para preparar comida, sillas y mesas.

loans.use:
Purchase of ingredients for meals, tables and chairs.

Compra de ingredietes para preparar alimentos, mesas y sillas

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum N. is 44 years old and the mother of 3 children.  Her husband is a construction worker in Phnom Penh.  One of her sons works in construction, and the other two drive motorcycle taxis to supplement the household income.  Sum N. sells fish in the local market, making approximately $3 per day.  Most of this loan will go to a motorbike for her sons so they can generate more income on their own.  The rest of it will go to increasing her fish trade.  In the future, the family plans to combine their incomes to build a more comfortable house.

loans.use: Expand Business, Buy motortaxi for her sons

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Cham

texts.en: Cham S. is 40 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her two young children and her husband.  She sells sugar cane juice and makes about $4 per day.  Her husband is a soldier and makes $1 per day.  Cham S. has been saving her money and is using this loan to build a small house that she will rent out to supplement her income from the sugar cane juice.   She looks forward to earning enough to build a new home for her and her family, as well as being able to send her children to university.

loans.use: Build a house to rent out

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn P. is 37 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her 3 children and husband. She sells vegetables at the market while her husband drives a Tuk-Tuk. Together, they can make between $20 and $30 a day.

Sorn P. will use this loan to buy a motorbike for her children so that her and her husband can focus more on their businesses. She feels they can generate far more income if they did not have to spend the time and money transporting their children to school each day. Sorn P. and her husband plan to work very hard so they can send all of their children to university and eventually into good jobs.

loans.use: To buy motorbike for children so she can stay at market

loans.name: Zenabu

texts.en: Zenab sells charcoal. She is seeking a loan of $800.00 from Kiva to help her expand. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Ms. Paulina E. has been running her business for 4 years. “My business is my only way of supporting my family. I am a single mother of two young children, and I am worried because my sales have gone down because my store lacks many items.” I am asking for $1,000.00 to stock my inventory and improve my sales.
Translated from Spanish by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Paulina E. tiene 4 años con su negocio “Mi negocio es la única manera que tengo de sostener a mi familia, soy mamá soltera de dos hijos menores de edad, estoy preocupada porque mis ventas han bajado un poco debido a que hay muchas cosas que me faltan". Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para surtir bien mi negocio y puedan aumentar mis ventas.

loans.use:
To invest in my business.

Invertir en mi negocio

loans.name: Nhatt

texts.en: Nhatt S. is 68 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her 3 children, her husband, and two of her nephews.  Two of her daughters work in a garment factory in the outskirts of the city, and they can each make $70-$80 per month.  Nhatt S. bakes a delicious roast beef snack that is commonly served alongside wine in Cambodia.  With this loan, she will buy the necessary equipment to increase her output and raise her income.  As she earns more profit, she plans to build a store where she can sell her snacks.

loans.use: Buying equipment for cooking business
