loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Ms. Minerva A. and her husband, Mr. Armando Tovar, have been running their business for 5 years. “We are located outside a very large market, and I would like to invest in more shoes since I lack many models and styles. I also need to buy a covering for the shoes to protect them from sun and rain.” I am asking for $1,000.00 to purchase footwear and protective coverings.
Translated from Spanish by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Minerva A. y su esposo el Sr. Armando Tovar tiene 5 años con su negocio “El lugar en donde estamos ubicados es afuera de un mercado muy grande me gustaría invertir en la compra de más calzado ya que me faltan muchos modelos y estilos diferentes, también necesito comprar una lona para cubrir el calzado del sol y de la lluvia”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para la compra de calzado y unas lonas para protección.

loans.use:
To purchase more footwear and protective coverings.

Comprar más Calzado y lonas de Protección.

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en:
Thuy was born in 1965. It is difficult for her to support both her old mother and her husband, who has injured feet, as well as her 3 children. Thuy's sons are students at secondary school. Her daughter is a student at high school. Thuy's family has only 1000 square meters for growing rice. Thuy's hut is 40 square meters, not enough for 6 people.

Thuy has grocery store in front of her hut. However, Thuy's main income from her grocery store is only $6 per person/month. She is very eager to receive a loan of $75 in order to increase the variety of goods in her grocery store. She believes that if her grocery store is expanded, she can get a higher income so that she is able to pay for school fees, and both her mother's and her husband's medicine. Thuy is going to repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To increase the variety for her grocery store.

El Sr. Angel M. tiene su negocio desde hace 1 año. “Mi negocio es de venta de Segunda (ropa usada), he querido comprar más ropa para la temporada de Primavera – Verano pero no he logrado por falta de recursos económicos”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para la compra de ropa.

To purchase clothing for my inventory.
Comprar ropa para mi negocio.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en: Julie and Ion P. are a hard working, honest, and responsible couple.  They are married with four children, two girl’s and two boy’s, with the oldest son now studying to become a dentist in the capitol of Moldova, Chisinau.   For the last ten years they have grown their agricultural business to have eight greenhouses totaling 2500 meters of which they grow tomatoes and cucumbers.  Julie is the primary caretaker of the greenhouses, because Ion works abroad in Moscow for three month time periods throughout the year ( The picture is of Ion in one of their greenhouses who recently came home to celebrate Easter with his family).  Julie would like to increase her productivity and has studied about the benefits of drip irrigation within greenhouses.  She would like a loan to purchase the required systems to implement irrigation within her greenhouses.

loans.use: To purchase drip irrigation system for her greenhouses.

She specializes in the sales of fresh tomatoes and onions. US$400 will be of great help to her in expanding the business.

loans.name: Severiano

texts.en:
Mr. Severiano has had his business for 2 years. he says: "My business is located in my own home and I need to expand a little bit because my space at the moment is rather small, I would also like to buy more merchandise and a wooden piece of furniture to display my fruits and vegetables." He is asking for a loan of $1,200.00 in order to expand his store, buy merchandise and a wooden piece of furniture.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

El Sr. Severiano tiene su negocio desde hace 2 años. “Mi negocio está ubicado en mi propia casa y necesito ampliar un poco ya que el espacio que tengo esta muy reducido, también me gustaría comprar más mercancía y un mueble de madera para poner frutas y verduras”. Solicito $ 1,200.00 dlls para ampliar mi negocio, comprar mercancía y un mueble de madera.

loans.use: To expand my business, to buy merchandise, and a wooden piece of furniture to display my fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Esohe

texts.en: 27 years old, Mrs. Esohe O. is married and has five children. She lives in the semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State of Nigeria. She learnt about the trade business for 4 years before she started her own beauty salon in the year 2003. Esohe is asking for US$400 to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Mr. M. has owned a mobile publicity business for the last 10 years. He began his business when he found that it was no longer easy to find employment because of his age. He plays mobile audio announcements from the streets and distributes publicity fliers. “I have always said that age doesn’t stop anyone from being a useful person who can take care of himself. That is why I began this business which has allowed my wife and me to progress. Nevertheless, the sound system that I use was purchased 10 years ago, and it is starting to break down. That is why I am asking for a $1,200 dollar loan to purchase a sound system more suitable for the job. This will help me to be more efficient in my mobile publicity business and my clients will see more success in the products that they offer.”

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. M. tiene un negocio de publicidad ambulante desde hace 10 años. Este negocio lo inició porque debido a su edad ya no era fácil encontrar empleo. Hace perifoneo por las calles y reparte volantes de publicidad. “Siempre he dicho que la edad no es obstáculo para seguir siendo una persona útil y obtener su propio sustento, por eso emprendí este negocio que me ha permitido sacar adelante a mi esposa y a mi mismo. Sin embargo, el equipo de sonido que utilizo lo compré hace 10 años, y ya está empezando a fallar. Por lo que requiero de un crédito de 1,200 dólares para adquirir un equipo de sonido que sea apto para mi trabajo. Esto me ayudará a ser más eficiente en mi servicio de publicidad ambulante y mis clientes tendrán mas éxito en los productos que ofrecen.

loans.use: Purchase of loudspeaker equipment

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Mama Alice sells cracked stones to construction firms through her business, Alice's Stone Quarry. She is a client of the Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited from the TEACH programme. She is seeking a loan of $850.00 from Kiva for working capital.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en: Auntie G. sells cracked stones to construction firms through her business, G.'s Quarry. She is a client of the Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited from the TEACH programme. She is seeking a loan of $850.00 from Kiva for working capital.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Mama Vic sells dry fish in her community. She is a client of the Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited from the TEACH programme. She is seeking a loan of $700.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Mr Yanez has had his business for one year. He says: "I would like to buy merchandise and a refrigerator for the sodas, milk, fruits and vegetables. I have not been able to purchase the needed items for lack of economic resources and my sales are low because of this." I ask for a loan of $1,000.00 to buy merchandise and a refrigerator.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

El Sr. Y. tiene su negocio en su casa desde hace 1 año. “Me gustaría comprar mercancía y un refrigerador para las sodas,la leche,las frutas y verduras, no he podido comprarlos por falta de recursos económicos y mis ventas son bajas debido a eso” SOLICITO $ 1,000.0 dlls para la compra de mercancía y un refrigerador.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and a refrigerator.

loans.name: Aku

texts.en: Aku sells cracked stones to construction firms through Aku's Quarry. She is a client of the Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited from the TEACH programme. She is seeking a loan of $850.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Mr. O. sells general goods through his business. He is a client of the Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited from the TEACH programme. He is seeking a loan of $700.00 from Kiva for working capital.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Santos

texts.en:
Mr. Robles sells purified water. He purchases the water in large plastic containers from distributers and then goes to the neighborhoods to sell his product from his old truck. He says: "I ask your help in order to purchase another vehicle from which I can continue to sell purified water as the truck I have now is worn-out and I don't believe it will last much longer. With $1,200.00 I can buy a newer model."

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

El Sr. Robles tiene la venta de agua purificada el compra al mayoreo los garrafones en las distribuidoras de agua y sale a las colonias a ofrecerla en una camioneta vieja. “Les pido su ayuda para poder comprar un vehiculo para seguir con la venta del agua purificada la troca que tengo ya está muy gastada y no creo que aguante por mucho tiempo, con $1,200.00 dlls podría conseguir otra de reciente modelo".

loans.use: To purchase another vehicle from which to sell purified water.

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.en:
Mrs. M. has a grocery store, she has stayed a long time at her current location, which she rents and despite this, her business does well as there are many customers in this part of the city. She says: " My intention is to have my own store, not rented, which is located in front of the storefront I have now, but to acheive this, I need financial support to be able to build my (new) store, I believe that $1,200.00 would help me to achieve my goal."

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

La Sra. M. tiene su tienda de abarrotes ella lleva tiempo en ese lugar rentando, a pesar de esto le va bien pues tiene mucha clientela por el sector de la ciudad. "Mi intención es tener mi tiendita en mi propio terreno el cual está ubicado enfrente de donde estoy, para lograr esto requiero de su apoyo para construir el local creo que con $1,200.00 dlls lograré mi objetivo".

loans.use: To change to location of her grocery store.

loans.name: Rosedanie

texts.en: Rosedanie A. L. is a street vendor in Tou-du-Nord, Haiti ,who sells cosmetics and hygienic products from a stall she sets up next to a local park. On top of running her business, Rosedanie raises her daughter who is able to attend school. This loA. will allow Rosedanie to increase her stock and start a new business selling gasoline to mainly motorcyclists who serve as public transportation in the narrows streets throughout the city. NOTE: Rosedanie is a member of A. Esperanza solidarity group. She and her business represent nine other micro-entrepreneurs who are members of the same solidarity group. Each members will receive a share of this $1,200 loA. to develop their respective businesses. The cost of living in Haiti is such that Esperanza is able to fund 10 entrepreneurs who must make each payment together. If one person is unable to pay, the other members must make up the difference before any payment will be accepted. The community of 10 entrepreneurs have gone through Esperanza´s business training courses and have demonstrated their commitment and aptitude for receiving a loA. to expand their business. Rosedanie and the other members are responsible for working with one another as a social support network throughout the loA. repayment and business development processes.

loans.use: Purchase soap, shampoo, perfume, cosmetics, toothpaste and various other hygienic products

loans.name: Flor Estela

texts.en:
Mrs. Flor Estela has run her business in her own home for 6 months. She says: "I have had my business for 6 months but because one of my sons passed away, I was closed for 1 month. Now I need to buy merchandise to be able to open once again, I have a very good location but I lack many things." She asks for a loan of $1,000.00 in order to buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

La Sra. Flor Estela tiene su negocio en su casa desde hace 6 meses. “Mi negocio lo tengo desde hace 6 meses pero debido al fallecimiento de uno de mis hijos lo tuve cerrado 1 mes, ahora necesito comprar mercancía para poder abrirlo otra ves, tengo muy buena ubicación pero me hacen falta muchas cosas” SOLICITO $ 1,000.0 dlls para la compra de mercancía

loans.use: To buy merchandise for the business.

loans.name: Ana Veronica

texts.en:
This is a family business, from Mrs Ana to her three children who all help tend to the store which is a small grocery store. They have two years of experience in this business and already have plans to expand. "We are growing and we have already ran out of space to buy merchandise in larger quantities, and so we need to expand our store, but to do so we need $1,200.00 which we hope will help us finalize our project."

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Este es un negocio familiar, desde la Sra. Ana hasta sus tres hijos están al pendiente de atender el negocio que es una tiendita de abarrotes llevan 2 años con este negocio y ya tienen planes para expandirse. "Estamos creciendo y ya no tenemos lugar para comprar mercancía en cantidades mayores por lo que necesitamos ampliar el lugar para esto se necesita $1,200.00 dlls esperamos y podamos terminar con nuestro proyecto.

loans.use: To expand my store and to stock merchandise.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes H. has opened her kitchen to the public and created a restaurant in her front yard. She lives with her son, Roberto, daughter, Santa Dominga, and her two grandchildren, all of whom she supports through her renowned cooking. She sets up shop outside her home which is just off the main highway that connects her home of San Pedro de Macoris with the Dominican capital, Santo Domingo. This loan will help her improve the quality of her restaurant by being able to purchase table cloths, additional chairs and tables, as well as more food for her rapidly growing customer base.


NOTE: Mercedes is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, which have all gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $1,000 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in a community and ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their business and family.

loans.use: Purchase food, furniture, accessories and tools for her restaurant.

loans.name: Andres

texts.en:
Mr S. has worked for 20 years at the repair and sales of electric domestic devices, and is an older person, but very responsible and dedicated to his work. He says: " What I desire is to continue working but to do this I need financial support in order to purchase a large quantity of used electric domestic devices to salvage the still-good parts and use them to repair the aparatuses that my clients bring to me, but I need a loan of $1,200.00."

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

El Sr. Seledón lleva 20 años dedicándose a la reparación y venta de electrodomésticos, es una persona mayor pero muy responsable y dedicada con su trabajo. "Lo que deseo es poder seguir ocupado en mi trabajo por eso necesito que me apoyen para poder comprar una gran cantidad de electrodomésticos usados para poder obtener las partes buenas y poder reparar todos los aparatos que me traigan los clientes, necesito un préstamo de $1,200.00 dlls

loans.use: To purchase new parts and used electric domestic devices to use to repairs and to sell.

loans.name: Misael

texts.en:
Mr. Misael C. has run a home based business for the last 6 years. “My wife and I have worked in our business for 6 years selling miscellaneous items and also new clothing. We purchase the clothing in another city where it costs us less, so that we can sell it to our customers on a layaway program where payments are made every two weeks. We need to purchase more clothing and a display case to hold it.” I am asking for a $1,200 dollar loan to purchase clothing for my business, and a display case in order to increase sales.”

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Misael C. tiene su negocio en su casa desde hace 6 años.”Mi esposa y yo trabajamos en este negocio desde hace 6 años vendiendo miscelánea y también ropa nueva que traemos de otra ciudad que es donde nos cuesta más barata para poder vendérselas a nuestros clientes en pagos quincenales, nos hace falta comprar más ropa y un mueble para acomodarla” SOLICITO $ 1,200.0 dlls para comprar ropa para mi negocio,un mueble y poder tener más ventas.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell and a display case

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra C. lives with her 6-year-old child, Francini Garcia, in a rural community outside San Pedro de Macoris, located east of the national capital on the southern coast of the Dominican Republic. She travels to the city to purchase jewellery, which she then sells to specific clients which are growing by word of mouth among her many friends and satisfied customers. The high value of her wares make it unwise to display her merchandise openly on a street corner, so she operates based on referals and makes house calls.

This loan will allow her to purchase more of the jewellery she sells, specifically rings, pendants, bracelets and earrings made of silver, pearls and particularly the native Dominican stones of Ambar - shaded in dark orange and brown tint - and Larimar, named after its hues that look like the blue waters of the Caribbean Sea.

NOTE: Sandra is the leader of her solidarity group called 'Mujeres en Desarollo' or "Women in Development." She and her business represent the four other members of her group, who each will receive a share of this $1,000 loan to fund their respective businesses. As members of a solidarity group, Sandra and the other four micro-entrepreneurs have gone through Esperanza´s business training courses and have proven to be committed to their businesses to provide for their families. If a member of the group is unable to make a payment, the other members are responsible for making up the difference and helping the person to improve. This group-lending method creates a social support network within the community as well as an accountability system to ensure that not only are loans paid back on time, but that the loan capital is invested in developing their business and providing for the basic necessities of their families.

loans.use: Purchase necklaces, bracelets, earrings and rings

loans.name: Karina Altagracia

texts.en:
Karina Altagracia and her husband raise their three young children, Jesibel, Alexia and Wilber; ages 5, 3 and 2, respectively. In order to provide for their children, Karina opened up her own beauty salon out of their home in a rural town called Los Guayacanes in the province of San Pedro de Macoris.

This loan will allow her to purchase a new hair styling machine as well as additional materials for her new business. Karina currently has only one machine for many clients and would like to hire an employee to run the extra chair and styling station that she will be able to purchase with this capital.

NOTE: Karina is a member of a Bank of Hope - a group of Esperanza micro-entrepreneurs in her community who help each other through the business management and loan repayment process. Karina and four other members of his solidarity group will be responsible for utilizing and paying back this loan of $1,000 together. Their respective businesses will each receive a share of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase a hair processor machine and other tools for her salon.

loans.name: Xavier

texts.en:
Xavier P., 45 years old, native of Montepuez, province of Cabo Delgado, grew up with his parents until he turned 20. His family's situation did not provide him the opportunity to study. He only reached 5th grade. In 1980, he was in the military and was demobilized in 1994, having opted to start his own commercial business.

He currently has a clothing sales shop, where he is the only worker.

With a loan of 10,500.00 mt, he plans to increase the volume of merchandise which will result in the increase of revenue and provide a better quality service to his customers.

His activity has a greater impact on the community because in addition to providing a job for himself, this allows him to earn income to support his family's basic expenses, put clothing articles on sale at competitive prices closer to customers who are residents of District 1 in Boane.

Translated from Portuguse by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 01 - Boane Cliente: Xavier P. Sector de actividade : Comercio Valor de empréstimo: 10.500,00 MT (420.00 US$) Aplicação de montante: Venda de Roupa Inicio: 02/04/2007 Fim: 31/03/2007 Xavier P. de 45 anos de idade, natural de Montepuez, província de Cabo Delgado, cresceu sob a responsabilidade dos pais ate atingir 20 anos, a situação financeira da família não lhe proporcionou oportunidades para estudar fez apenas 5@ classe. Em 1980 esteve na vida militar e foi desmobilizado em 1994, tendo de seguida optado por iniciar seu próprio negocio de actividade comercial. Actualmente conta com uma banca de venda de roupa, onde ele é o único trabalhador. Com empréstimo de 10.500,00 mt pretende aumentar o volume de mercadoria o que vai resultar no aumento dos rendimentos e proporcionar um serviço de qualidade para seus clientes. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque alem de providenciar emprego para ele próprio o que lhe permite obter rendimentos para suportar despesas básicas da família, coloca artigos de vestuário apreços competitivos mais perto dos clientes residentes no bairro 1 de Boane.

loans.use: To increase the stock of used clothing in his shop

loans.name: Rafael

texts.en:
Rafael has run his small business from his home for the last 4 months. “My business needs a lot more merchandise. I have purchased a few things, but it is not enough. I would like to grow, and to purchase display cases for the merchandise. I also need a scale to weigh fruit and vegetables. I am asking for $1,200 dollars to grow my business, and to purchase a scale and merchandise.”

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Rafael tiene un pequeño negocio en su casa desde hace 4 meses “Mi negocio necesita muchas mercancía he comprado algunas cosas pero no es suficiente, quisiera ampliar un poco y comprar muebles para acomodar la mercancía, me hace falta comprar una báscula para pesar las frutas y verduras” SOLICITO $ 1,200.0 dlls para ampliar mi negocio,comprar mercancia y una báscula.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and a scale.

loans.name: Manuel Jorge

texts.en:
Manuel Jorge Marta D. S., 47 years old, native of Mopeia, Province of Zambezia, grew up with his parents. His family's situation did not proviD. him opportunities for studying.

In 1998, he started to work with commercial activities and he took charge of the management of his family's business. At the start of 2007, through friends, he learned about HLUVUKU-ADSEMA and approached them for more information. After getting information, he decided to present his loan request, with the goal of expanding the volume of his business, improving the quality of customer service and increasing revenue. His activity has a greater impact on the community, because in addition to providing a job for himself, he employs one additional person and providens high quality meals to everyone who visit the Massaca District, which has great tourist potential, since it is located near Barragem dos Pequenos Libombos.

Translated by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

Localização: Bairro Massaca - Boane Cliente: Manuel Jorge Marta D. S. Sector D. ActividaD.: Serviços Valor D. Empréstimo: 13.000,00 MT (520.00US$) Aplicação do Empréstimo: Venda D. Refeições Início: 10/04/2007 Fim: 31/03/2007 Manuel Jorge Marta D. S. D. 47 anos D. idaD., Natural D. Mopeia Província D. Zambezia, cresceu sob a responsabilidaD. dos seus Pais, a situação financeira da sua família não lhe criou oportunidades para estudar. Em 1998 começou a trabalhar com a actividaD. Comercial e vem assumindo na integra a gestão D. negocio da família e conta hoje com uma instalação social. Nos princípios D. 2007 por indicação D. alguns amigos, teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-DSEMA tendo se aproximado para obter informações. Depois D. se informar, decidiu apresentar o seu pedido D. empréstimo cujo objectivo é ampliar o seu volume D. negócio, melhorar a qualidaD. D. serviços ao cliente e aumentar os rendimentos. A sua actividaD. tem um impacto maior na comunidaD. porque alem D. proporcionar emprego para ele próprio, emprega mais uma pessoa e providencia refeições D. qualidaD. para todos os que visitam o Bairro da Massaca com um granD. potencial turístico, pois localiza-se nas proximidades da Barragem dos Pequenos Libombos.

loans.use: To increase stock for his restaurant

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara C. has created a business selling various food staples as well as new and used clothing. Her business supports her family and she hopes to fulfill her goal of being able to send all of her children to college. Her oldest son, Keni (17) assists her after school by looking after his two younger siblings, Sandra (12) and Luis (8) while their mother works. This loan will allow Sara to have the capital she needs to invest in developing her business. Right now she has limited resources and a small inventory, but her business plan and training that she went through with Esperanza has prepared her to move ahead in her business growth process with this first loan.

NOTE: Sara is one of 5 micro-entrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, which have all gone through Esperanza's business training courses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their shares of this $1,000 loan together. If a member is unable to pay in full on time, the group is responsible for making up the deficit before a payment can be made. Investors in this loan will receive an update on Sara's progress as well as that of the entire group. This group-lending method strengthens social needs in a community and ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their business and family.

loans.use: Purchase clothing as well as coffee, fruit, beans and rice

loans.name: Constância José

texts.en:
Constância José C., 27 years old, native of Bilene, Province of Gaza. She grow up with her parents, and had few opportunities to study due to the family's lack of financial resources. This made her enter the world early, having to interrupt her studies for an early marriage.

The family has a micro-business building furniture. The raw material used is wood, which is acquired in the large lumber companies in the city of Maputo, about 30 km from the town of Boane, where her carpentry shop is located.

At the end of 2006, through neighbors, she found out about Hluvuku-Adsema and, since she needed to increase her stock of wood, and didn't have a place to turn to for the loan, this was a great opportunity. With a loan of US$600, she plans to purchase wood for building various types of furniture ordered by her customers and to increase the family income to apply to her carpentry business.

Her activity has a larger impact on the community because, in addition to providing a job for three people, she makes high quality furniture available at accessible prices near to where her customers are located.

Translated from Portuguese by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 1– Boane

Cliente: Constância José C.

Sector de actividade: Transformação

Valor de empréstimo: 15.000,00MT (600.00US$)

Aplicação de montante: Compra de madeira para fabrico de mobília

Inicio: 10/04/07

Fim: 31/03/2008

Constância José C. de 27 anos de idade, natural de Bilene, Província de Gaza. Cresceu sob responsabilidade dos Pais, teve poucas oportunidades de estudar for falta de recursos financeiros na família que lhe fez vir ao mundo, teve de interromper os estudos para casamento prematuro.

A família possui uma micro empresa de fabrico de mobília anexo a residência, a sua principal matéria prima é madeira que é adquirida nas grandes serrações da cidade de Maputo que dista 30 Kms da vila de Boane, onde localiza-se a sua carpintaria.

Nos finais do ano de 2006 por indicações dos vizinhos teve conhecimento de existência da Hluvuku-Adsema e como necessitava de aumentar o stock de madeira e não tinha onde recorrer para obter empréstimo, esta foi a grande oportunidade. Com empréstimo de 600.00US$ pretende aplicar na compra de madeira para fabrico de vários tipos de mobília encomendada pelos clientes e aumentar a renda familiar. para aplicação do seu negócio na carpintaria.

A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque para alem de providenciar emprego para três pessoas, coloca a mobília de qualidade e apreços acessíveis mais perto do cliente.

loans.use: TO buy wood for produce furniture

loans.name: Noris

texts.en:
Noris G. lives and raises her two daughters, 10-year-old Joann and 5-year-old Yomydi, in the rural town of Restauracion in the province of San Pedro de Macoris, located on the south coast of the Dominican Republic. She runs a business selling filtered water packets and coconut-flavoured ice cream. Since potable tap water is not available in most cities throughout the Dominican Republic, filtered water is in high demand, whether for rehydrating against the high Caribbean temperatures or to wash and prepare food.

This loan will allow her to increase her inventory of water, which is filtered and sealed into plastic bags in about 6-ounce quantities. She will also be able to purchase ice and ingredients for making frozen sweets so that she can take full advantage of her new refrigerator.

NOTE: This $1,000 loan will go to fund Noris' business, as well as four other businesses within her solidarity group. She and four other micro-entrepreneurs in her community came to Esperanza and formed their own group, which they named 'Por Fe Vivimos' or "We Live by Faith." They have all gone through Esperanza's business training program and will receive shares of this $1,000 loan to invest in their respective businesses and pay back the loan together. The entire group must pay in full and on time, otherwise group members must make up the deficit before any payment can be made. This creates accountability among the group members because each one shares in the success and struggles of the other members in their group.

loans.use: Purchase filtered water packets and expand inventory of four other businesses.

loans.name: Sineta Mário

texts.en:
Sineta Mario M., 39 years old, native of Boane, has 3 children. Her early marriage forced her to interrupt her studies when she was at level 4. She had her third child when she was abandoned by her husband (who got together with another woman) and in order to survive, she started a business selling beef. She purchased the cow in the provinces in the center of Mozambique (Tete, Sofala and Manica). Year later, she decided to change businesses.

She started to raise chickens on her own, based on the experience of family members who had done the same kind of business. Through neighbors, she found out about Hluvuku-Adsema in 2006 and approached them to get more information about how to access credit.

With this loan, she plans to increase the quantity of chickens and reduce the production cycles in order to always have chicken meat available for the community, significantly increasing her monthly income.

Her activity has a positive impact on the community, since she provides a job for herself and her oldest child, who is the father of 2 children, in addition to ensuring the supply of animal protein for her community.

Translated from Portuguese by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 7 - Boane

Cliente: Sineta Mário M.

Sector de actividade: Avicultura

Valor de empréstimo: 19.000,00MT (775.00US$)

Aplicação de montante : Compra de pintos de engorde.

Inicio: 10/04/07

Fim: 31/03/2008

Sineta Mario M. de 39 anos de idade, natural de boane, tem 3 filhos. O casamento pre-maturo obrigou lhe a interromper os estudos quando fazia a 4@ classe. Tinha o seu terceiro filho, quando foi abandona da pelo marido (que foi juntar-se com outra mulher) e como forma de sobrevivência começou um negocio de venda de carne de vaca, comprava o gado bovino nas províncias do centro de Moçambique (Tete, Sofala e Manica). Anos depois decidiu mudar do tipo de negocio.

Começou a criar frangos de engorde com meios próprios, baseando-se na experiência antiga dos seus familiares que outrora fazia o mesmo tipo de negocio.

Através dos vizinhos soube da existência da Hluvuku - Adsema em 2006 e tendo aproximado para obter mais informações sobre as condições de acesso ao crédito.

Com este empréstimo pretende aumentar a quantidade de pintos de engorde e reduzir os ciclos de produção para ter frango sempre disponível para a comunidade, aumentando significativamente a sua receita mensal.

A sua actividade tem um impacto positivo na comunidade, pois providencia emprego para ela própria e seu filho primogénito que já é pai de 2 filhos, para alem de garantir proteína animal para sua comunidade.

loans.use: To raise chickens

loans.name: Eusebia

texts.en:
Eusebia would like to improve the area that she uses for clothing sales. She has had her business for 3 years, and is assisted by her daughter. “The vegetation around my house provides the area with nice shade, but it isn’t enough when the rain interrupts sales and damages the merchandise. I am requesting a $1,200 dollar loan.”

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Eusebia manifiesta el deseo de mejorar el lugar que ocupa para la venta de su ropa ella tiene 3 años haciendo esto, le ayuda su hija. "Tengo muy buena sombra producida por la vegetación de mi casa pero no es suficiente pues las lluvias interrumpen la venta y maltratan la mercancía, el préstamo solicitado es de $1,200.00 dlls".

loans.use: Construction of a thached roof to cover merchandise offered for sale.

loans.name: Aipopo

texts.en: Aipopo supports herself and her family by weaving traditional Samoan mats.  In the traditional Samoan household, there is little, if any, furniture and mats are an important part of daily life.  Mats are spread out on the floor of the traditional, open structured Samoan house (fale) and used to sit on for family gatherings and meals as well as village meetings.  Aipopo is one of the Samoan women that keeps the tradition of mat weaving alive; she uses all local, natural materials such as palm and other leaves (taiga laufala) to make her mats.  Aipopo is able to sell mats to local villagers for family use as well as to make fine, large mats for export to America.  Abroad, Aipopo’s mats can command high prices.  Aipopo is seeking a loan so that she can purchase the materials necessary to continue to make fine Samoan mats for export.  A loan to Aipopo not only helps her provide for her children, but also supports the traditional Samoan craft of mat weaving.

loans.use: Buy materials for weaving traditional mats

loans.name: Marta Augusto

texts.en:
Marta Augusto M., 27 years old, native of Manhiça, Province of Maputo, widow and resident of district 7. She grew up with her parents in the countryside and was not able to escape the problems that many families with few resources suffer from - the lack of school education.

In 1997, after 7th grade, she abandoned school for an early marriage, having chosen to create her own business along with her husband. Her main activity is purchasing one-day chickens to raise and then sell in the local market. She currently has a chicken house in the yard of her home, and she employs a person who sells the chickens, as well as supplying fresh chicken meat to the community.

Translated from Portuguese by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 7 - Boane

Cliente: Marta augusto M.

Sector de actividade: Avicultura

Valor de empréstimo: 12.000,00MT (480.00US$)

Aplicação de montante: Compra de pintos de engorde.

Inicio: 10/04/2007

Fim: 31/03/2008 Marta Augusto M. de 27 anos de idade, natural de Manhiça, Província de Maputo, viúva e residente do bairro 7. Cresceu na responsabilidade dos seus pais camponeses e não escapou as dificuldades de falta de educação escolar como passa com muitas famílias de pouca posse.

Em 1997, com a 7@ classe abandonou a escola para casamento prematuro, tendo optado por criar seu próprio negocio junto com o marido.

A sua principal actividade é compra de pintos de (um) 1 dia para posterior engorde e venda no mercado local.

Actualmente conta com uma capoeira dentro do quintal da casa dela e emprega uma pessoa que faz as vendas dos frangos, para alem de fornecer carne fresca de frangos a comunidade.

loans.use: Chickens produce

loans.name: Gladis

texts.en:
Gladis E. says she is in the right business for raising her six growing children, ages 7, 11, 12, 13, 15 and 16. She runs her own bakery, which allows her to directly provide for much of the food for her household as well as a steady source of income to take care of immediate needs. Gladis requests this loan to purchase a bread-maker and additional ingredients such as flour and oil so that she can create enough bread to be a main distributor in her rural town outside the capital of San Pedro de Macoris. The profits she makes are invested in her business and go to savings for her children's education, which she says is one of her primary dreams for her children.

NOTE: This $1,000 will fund Gladis' business plus 4 others in her community. She and four additional entrepreneurs have formed a solidarity group that received business training from Esperanza and will be responsible for paying back this loan together as they develop their respective businesses. This group-lending methodology fosters accountability among the members because they all must pay in full and on time.

loans.use: Purchase additional bread-making machine, baking ingredients and coffee

loans.name: Animoe

texts.en: Animoe’s husband died many years ago; his death left her alone with two small daughters to support.  She raised her daughters alone, using her small vegetable garden to bring in the necessary income.  Today, Animoe lives alone in the Samoan village of Aleisa.  She still uses her garden, in which she mainly cultivates ginger, to support herself.  Animoe works hard to care for her gardens, and every Saturday she travels to the market to sell the ginger and other vegetables she has grown.  Animoe has been an active, upstanding member of her village’s SPBD Center.  She was recently elected the President of the Aleisa SPBD Center and has also held the post of Secretary.  Having repaid previous loans in full, Animoe is now eligible for her fourth SPBD loan, which she will use for seeds and fertilizers to further enhance the productivity of her Ginger Garden.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Leontina Felismina

texts.en:
Leontina Felismina C., 39 years old, native of Chidenguele, province of Gaza, grew up with her parents, and only studied through the 4th level.

Since 1990, she has been taking care care of her family's business and has 2 commercial establishments in the district of Campoane. As of last year, 2006, through friends in the Campoane market, she found out about Hluvuku-Adsema, and requested a loan at the start of April to expand her business. With the loan, she plans to increase the volume of her business, offering better quality products, and a better quantity, to the community, and thus increasing her monthly revenue.

The impact of her activity is visible in the community, since it ensures the supply of basic goods and self-employment to support her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

Localização: Campoane - Boane

Cliente: Leontina Felismina C.

Sector de actividade: Comercio

Valor de empréstimo: 15.000,00MT (600.00US$)

Aplicação de montante: Compra e venda de produtos

Inicio: 10/04/2007

Fim: 31/03/2008

Leontina Felismina C., de 39 anos de idade, natural de Chidenguele, provincial de Gaza cresceu na responsabilidade, apenas estudou até 4@ classe.

Desde o ano 1990 vem assumindo a gestão do negocio da família e possui 2 estabelecimentos comerciais no bairro de Campoane. A partir do ano passado 2006 por indicações de amigos do mercado Campoane teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA, tendo solicitado um empréstimo no principio de Abril para ampliação do negocio.

Com o empréstimo pretende aumentar o volume de negocio, oferecendo produtos de melhor qualidade e quantidade a comunidade, aumentando desta forma a sua renda mensal.

O impacto da sua actividade é visível na comunidade, pois garante o abastecimento de produtos básicos e auto emprego para sustento da sua familia.

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

loans.name: Logo

texts.en: Logo’s husband works full-time and earns about ST 150 per week.  Leveraging her horticulture talents, Logo can often bring in more than that by selling the flowers and plants that she raises in her backyard.  Logo’s talents are so well known in her village that her local customers generally seek her out at home to purchase her renowned flora.  The income from her sales is a necessary contribution to meeting the needs of her family of six.  Counted among her dependents is Logo’s elderly mother, who relies on Logo and her husband for care and financial support.  Providing a loan to Logo will allow her to purchase the additional supplies (seeds, fertilizer, pots) necessary to expand the supply and the types of potted plants, flowers and herbs she can offer her customers.

loans.use: Buy seeds, pots, fertilizers to enhance her product offering

loans.name: Luana

texts.en: Luana is a young mother of three children.  The income from her sewing business is critical for her family being able to afford the school fees and school supplies necessary to educate her children.  Luana works 6–7 days every week to make popular Samoan clothing for sale to local villagers.  She makes the dresses that Somoan women commonly wear (Puletasis) and the button down shirts that Somoan men typically wear (Aloa).  Luana is very active in her village’s SPBD Center and serves as Secretary.  Luana has been able to use past SPBD loans to buy the materials and supplies necessary to start up her small sewing business.  Her solid track record of on-time repayment makes her eligible for her fourth loan, which she will use to expand her product line to include printed fabrics, which she will design and print herself. (Referred to locally as Elei printing.)

loans.use: Buy material and fabric printing supplies

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Clara S. A. has turned her cooking skills into a steady source of income for her and her two children - Rudy (19) and Wilki (15). After suffering a severe injury while working in an industrial Free Zone near her home in San Pedro de Macoris, she lost the use of her left arm, but began cooking and selling home-cooked meals to families in her community to support her family financially. This loan will go towards purchasing new equipment and more food to increase her production and lead her to greater profits, which will help her save up enough to one day purchase a prosthetic limb.

NOTE: Clara and four other micro-entrepreneurs are part of a solidarity group designed by Esperanza to create a social network and accountability system. Clara and every other member in her group will receive an equal share of this $1,200 loan to develop their own businesses to support their families. They also provide ongoing advice for each other and help one another make payments on their loans. This group-lending method has proven to be a highly effective way to ensure accountability and support.

loans.use: Purchase cooking utensils, additional pots and pans, meat and vegetables

loans.name: J Socorro

texts.en:
Mr. G. owns a small restaurant. He wishes to advertise his business, and is asking for financial support so that he can advertise and offer wider variety on his menu. “I would like everyone in the city to come by and try the delicious stews prepared by the woman who assists me. I am asking for $1,200.00.”

Translated from Spanish by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. G. cuenta con un pequeño restaurante, el desea dar a conocer su negocio, solicita apoyo para la publicidad y para tener mas variedad en su menú gastronómico. "Quiero que toda la gente de la ciudad venga a probar los guisos riquísimos que son elaborados por parte de la señora que me ayuda, el apoyo solicitado es de $1,200.00 dlls".

loans.use:
For advertising and a wider variety of dishes.
Para publicidad y mas variedad de platillos.

loans.name: Maina

texts.en: Maina is an active member of SPBD with a strong history of on-time loan payments, and she is currently seeking her fifth loan.  Maina runs a successful fast food stall at the Flea Market in the village of Savalalo six days every week.  She is able to sell thirty to fifty plates of food each week, and the income from her food sales help support her family, send her children to school and make home improvements.  Maina will use her next loan to purchase upgraded cooking equipment for her fast food stall.

loans.use: Buy upgraded cooking equipment for her fast food stall

loans.name: Pasikalia

texts.en: Pasikalia lives with her family on Samoa’s seashore.  Her and her family’s sole source of income is the family fishing business that Pasikalia and her husband work together to manage.  While her husband is the primary fisherman, Pasikalia is adept at planning / optimizing the amounts she takes to market and the prices she offer.  Pasikalia has been able to fund expansion of the family’s business via SPBD loans, and with a strong history of on-time repayment, she is now eligible for her fourth SPBD loan, which she will use for upgrading the fishing equipment.  While their ability to secure a good catch is often dependent on the weather, a good week with cooperative weather can bring in almost ST 1,000 (USD 350) per week, making the family’s fishing business a viable source of income for Pasikalia’s family.

loans.use: :  Buy upgraded equipment for her family’s fishing business

loans.name: Martha Laura

texts.en:
Martha Laura is a married mother with two small children. She is 39 years old and is originally from the city of Monterrey in the state of Nuevo Leon. She worked for four years in an airport but needed to stop this work in order to care for her children. In order to solve some economic problems in the family that could not be solved with the salary of her husband alone, Martha saw the need to start a food sales business. With this she could look after her children while helping with family expenses.

Little by little this business has increased to include the sales of tomales and tacos. She also now caters banquets and parties. She needs a loan of $750 to inest in her business and continue growing. You can form a part of the growth of this business and improve the life of this family.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Martha Laura es casada, madre de dos pequeños niños, tiene 39 años y es originaria de la ciudad de Monterrey, en el estado de Nuevo León. Hace cuatro años trabajaba en el aeropuerto pero tuvo que dejar el empleo para atender a sus hijos y su hogar, al dejar de obtener ingresos, su familia paso por problemas económicos que no se podían resolver sólo con el salario de su esposo Manuel, por lo que Doña Lauris, como le dicen, se vio en la necesidad de emprender un negocio de venta de comidas, con lo que podía atender su casa y apoyar con los gastos familiares.

Inició con pocos platillos y poco a poco su negocio ha incrementado e incorporó la venta de tamales, y diversos guisos para tacos, que ahora vende al mayoreo, para banquetes y fiestas. Necesita un préstamo de $ 750 dólares para invertir en su negocio y continuar creciendo. Forma parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio, tú puedes ayudar a mejorar la vida de esta familia.

loans.use:
Investment in family business

Compra de insumos

loans.name: Blanca Estela

texts.en:
Blanca Estela is 35 years old and is originally from the city of Monterrey. She is married and has two small children. She sells cosmetics. She started this two years ago to help her husband support the family. Little by little the business has grown and is now a leader of sales for a product line she represents. Right now, she is working on developing a team of sales people. Her goal is to become the number one seller in her area. She is working very hard to create an excellent sales team to excel with its results.

She currently needs a loan of $925 to increase her inventory and cover distribution costs and continue growing her business. Your help will contribute to the growth of this business and help Blanca make her dream a reality.

La señora Blanca Estela tiene 35 años, es originaria de la ciudad de Monterrey, es casada y tiene de dos pequeños hijos. Se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y productos para el hogar por catálogo. Inició hace dos años con la finalidad de apoyar a su esposo con el ingreso familiar, pero poco a poco ha ido haciendo crecer sus ventas, hasta convertirse en líder de la Compañía para la que labora, actualmente está creando su propia red de vendedoras. Su meta es pronto convertirse en la número uno de la zona y por eso esta trabajando fuertemente para crear un equipo de ventas excelente y sobresalir por sus resultados.

En este momento necesita un crédito por 925 dólares que empleará en incrementar su inventario de mercancía que le permita cubrir las necesidades de sus distribuidoras, y continuar creciendo. Con tu ayuda puedes contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio, y a lograr que Blanca cumpa su sueño, no lo dudes más.

loans.use:
Purchase merchandise

Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Saina

texts.en: Saina is the proprietor of one of the busiest stores in her village.  Her store is open from 6.00a – 10.00p seven days a week.  Saiana’s hard work and strong performance history has made it possible for her to be eligible for her fifth SPBD loan.  She is one of the longest-running SPBD members in her region, and her success has been a strong example for other women entrepreneurs in the region.  She has used the previous four SPBD loans to start up and finance the growth of her shop, and she is seeking a fifth loan to improve the reliability of her supply and further expand the products available to the local villagers.

loans.use: :  Enhance, stock and expand her village store

loans.name: Maria Idalia

texts.en:
Maria idalia is 41 years old and is divorced with two children. She started a clothing sales business in her home town of Monterrey in order to pay for personal expenses and the education of her children. She started with a little merchandise and little by little she has increased her sales and clientele. It has not been easy for Maria to carry all of the responsibilities of ehr house but the love of her children makes it worth it.

Actually, Maria needs a loan of $475 to buy new merchandise to have new sales and new clients. Maria will repay this loan in 5 to 10 months. You can contribute to improving the living conditions of this family. Your help is a great blessing for them.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maria Idalia tiene 41 años de edad, es divorciada y es madre de dos hijos. Ella emprendió su negocio de venta de ropa en la ciudad de Monterrey, Nuevo León, de donde es originaria para sobrelleva sus gastos personales y los de la educación de sus hijos. Inicio con poca mercancía pero poco a poco ha ido incrementando sus ventas y sus clientes, no ha sido fácil para Maria cargar con todas las responsabilidades de su casa, pero el amor y el bienestar de sus hijos es su recompensa al esfuerzo.

Actualmente necesita un crédito por $ 475 dólares para compra de mercancía que le permita incrementar la variedad de su ropa así como sus ventas y pueda tener más y nuevos clientes, Maria se compromete a regresar este préstamo en un lapso de 5 a 10 meses. Tú puedes contribuir a mejorar las condiciones de vida de esta familia, tu apoyo será de gran bendición para ellos.

loans.use:
Purchase Merchandise

Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Eduardo David

texts.en:
Eduardo is 31 years old and is originally from the city of Monterrey, in the state of Nuevo León. he is married and the father of two small children. Eduardo has been a metalworker and automotive painter for over five years. When he became unemployed, he decided to start his own business and provide this service in order to obtain the resources he needed to support and educate his family. Little by little, with his efforts, he has been able to improve his business, becoming known in his area and expanding his client base.

At this time, he needs credit in the amount of $475 because he is going to work on automotive paint projects and improve the quality of service he offers to his customers, which will allow him to obtain better revenue. Eduardo needs your help to be able to grow his business. Your help can improve his and his family's lives should you decide to support them.

Translated from Spanish by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

Eduardo tiene 31 años es originario de la ciudad de Monterrey, en el estado de Nuevo León, es casado y padre de dos pequeños hijos. Eduardo hojalatero y pintor automotriz desde hace más de cinco años, al verse desempleado decidió iniciar su propio negocio y brindar este servicio por la necesidad de obtener los recursos que necesita para el sustento y la educación de su familia. Poco a poco y con base en su esfuerzos ha logrado mejorar su negocio, dándose a conocer en la zona y ha logrando tener más clientes.

En este momento requiere el crédito por la cantidad de $ 475 dólares porque va a trabajar en proyectos de pintura automotriz y mejorar la calidad del servicio que ofrece a sus clientes, esto le permitirá obtener mejores ingresos. Eduardo necesita de tu colaboración para poder crecer con su negocio, tu ayuda puede mejorar la vida de él y su familia, decídete a apoyarlos.

loans.use: Purchase materials

loans.name: Alma Nelly

texts.en:
Mrs. Alma Nelly is 31 years old, is married and the mother of 2 small children. Her husband, Saúl, is employeed in security, but the salary he receives does not cover the family's basic needs. For this reason, Alma started selling cosmetics and products for the home by catalog two years ago. She started with a small amount of capital loaned by her husband and has made it into a good business, thanks to the enthusiasm with which she does her work and the good relationships she has in her friendships. Little by little, her business has grown and she has been able to expand her client base and her sales.

At this time, Alma Nelly needs credit in the amount of $475, which she will use to purchase merchandise to be able to meet her clients' orders, offer good service and continue growing her business. She intends to repay the loan in a period of 5 to 10 months. Alma needs your help, and you can be an important part of her success. She nad her family sincerely thank you for your support.

Translated from Spanish by Naomi Baer, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Alma Nelly tiene 31 años de edad, es casada y madre de 2 hijos pequeños, su esposo Saúl es empleado de seguridad, pero el salario que recibe no cubre las necesidades básicas de su familia, razón por la que Alma inició con las ventas de cosméticos y productos para el hogar por catalogo, desde hace dos años. Comenzó con un pequeño capital que le prestó su esposo y se ha convertido en un buen negocio gracias al entusiasmo con que ella realiza su labor y a las buenas relaciones que tiene con sus amistades, poco a poco ha ido creciendo y ha logrado aumentar sus clientes y sus ventas.

En estos momentos Alma Nelly necesita de un crédito por la cantidad de $ 475 dólares que utilizara en la compra de mercancía para poder surtir los pedidos de sus clientes, ofrecer un buen servicio y continuar creciendo con su negocio, ella esta dispuesta a retornar el préstamo en un lapso de 5 a 10 meses. Alma necesita de tu ayuda, tú puedes ser parte importante en sus logros, ella y su familia agradecen sinceramente tu apoyo.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Solialii

texts.en: Solialii’s runs a stand at the flea market in the Samoan village of Fugalei.  Solialii sells her goods to local customers and tourists alike, and most of what Solialii stocks is handmade by her and her husband using Samoan materials, especially coconut shells.  Solialii has a long history with SPBD.  She is very active and reliable participant in her local SPBD Center’s activities and is currently seeking her fourth loan, having paid back the previous three in full and on time.  Solialii would use this fourth loan to further expand her product line and differentiate her flea market stall from local competitors.

loans.use: Expand the products available to her local customers

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise B. has three businesses. She bakes bread, which she sells to street vendors to resell, and she also sells apparel and clothing accessories - all from her home in a rural town outside the capital of Hato Mayor province. Francoise lives with her 19-year-old daughter, Daniela. This loan will go towards the purchase of clothing, shoes and accessory kits which she buys in the city to re-sell in her village. She will also be able to buy more baking materials to expand her small bakery business.

Francoise is a member of a Bank of Hope solidarity group - made up of five micro-entrepreneurs who have gone through Esperanza's business training programme and have proven to be in need of a loan as well as able to pay it back. Each member will receive a share of this $1,000 loan to develop their respective businesses and are responsible for making each loan repayment together, which fosters accountability as well as social support.

loans.use: Purchase flour, clothes and accessories

loans.name: Teleuli

texts.en: Teleuli, her husband and their five children rely on the income generated from a single taxi.  Provided the car is in good shape and her husband can drive long hours six days per week, the income generated by the taxi is enough to cover the weekly expenses of her large family.  Given that her family is dependent on the auto as their sole source of income, Teleuli works hard to ensure it is in good shape.  She is seeking a loan to use for necessary auto repairs.  With this money, Teleuli can ensure that she and her husband can continue to run a reliable taxi service and provide for their family.

loans.use: Auto repairs

loans.name: Utuagiagi

texts.en: Utuagiagi has a strong history with the SPBD.  She is seeking her fourth loan, with the previous three loans having been fully paid on schedule.  She has used the SPBD loans to fund the start-up and growth of her fishing business, which is her sole means of support.  Utuagiagi lives in a small Samoan village by the sea and is one of the few female fishermen on the island.  Most women who participate in fishing industries do so on or close to the shore, but Utuagiagi takes the risks inherent in going out to sea alone in her small boat to increase her catch.  An additional loan will help Utuagiagi obtain the necessary supplies and repairs to continue to support herself via her fishing production.

loans.use: Fund continued growth of her fishing business by purchasing necessary repairs and supplies

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria A. is the mother of five children, all boys, ages 16, 14 (pictured), 13, 11 and 5. 

Maria builds furniture out of a 10'x 10' workshop adjacent to her home in Hato Mayor. She constructs tables, shelving, dressers, chairs and couches, which she sells to larger stores in the city. 

This loan will go towards the purchase of wood, not only for making furniture, but also to construct a larger workbench to saw and drill on. She will also be able to purchase a motor for her power tools.

Maria has received two previous loans and paid them back with the substantial earnings she receives from her steady source of clientele.

loans.use: Purchase a motor, a saw blade and wood to build furniture as well as a work bench.

loans.name: Ateliana

texts.en: Ateliana leverages her skills in traditional Samoan weaving to support her family.  She weaves tablemats, hand fans and floor mats.  She has regular customers at the local market where she sells her handmade goods.  Ateliana can earn up to ST 95 (approximately USD 36) a day from her sales.  The income is a critical contribution to supporting her family and keeping her children in school.  Ateliana happily tells about the satisfaction and confidence she has earned since using the SPBD loans to be able to expand her product line and keep a consistent supply of goods for sale.  She enjoys the time she spends at the market selling her goods, as it gives her some exercise and time outside the home.  Ateliana is committed to her business and leveraging her talents to earn income for the sake of her family.

loans.use: Buy additional weaving supplies

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz Vasques owns and operates a small grocery stand on the street corner next to her home. She lives there with her husband and their six year old son. Her business is one of the main sources of household items, cooking supplies and food staples in her barrio in Villa Navarro outside Hato Mayor. Luz is even able to afford an extra employee.

This loan will give Luz the capital to replenish her store with canned food, rice, beans, bread, plantains, candy, and beverages. She has a refrigerator to keep perishable items and ample space to store a larger inventory so she can offer more goods to her customers.

Luz is a member of an Esperanza solidarity group. She and the four other members of her group will receive shares of this $1,000 loan to develop their small businesses. They have gone through business traning together and have proved to have good ability and commitment to conducting their work and supporting their family. They will make each repayment together and investors in this business will receive an update on not only the progress of Luz, but that of her group as well.

loans.use: Replenish inventory

loans.name: Faapopole

texts.en: Faapopole S. makes flavored ices (locally referred to as “ice cakes”).  Her customers are the locals in her village; the local primary school children are especially good customers of hers.  Faapopole is committed to being a successful businesswoman; she feels confident that she can succeed and puts most a lot of effort into ensuring her business succeeds.  Her family is very supportive of her efforts.  Faapopole’s entrepreneurial spirit now allows her family to pay their electricity and water bills as well as the children’s school fees.  A loan will help Faapopole purchase supplies for her business and particularly will allow her to purchase bottled spring water to make her product.  Using bottled water is necessary for Faapopole to make a safe product.

loans.use: :  Buy supplies for her flavored ice business, e.g. sugar, cordial, spring water, plastic bags

loans.name: Solialofi

texts.en: Soli is a 33-year old woman with three school-age children.  In order to improve the life of her family and her children, she set up a canteen at the local primary school.  She cooks and sells food at the school and can earn up to ST 95 (approximately USD 36) a day; this income is a critical contribution to covering her family’s expenses and makes her the primary breadwinner in her family.  Soli has used a previous SPBD loan to purchase equipment, and her previous success now qualifies her for a second loan.  She has hopes of enlarging her business, now that she sees how high the local demand is for her food.  She will use additional loan funds to purchase canteen supplies (e.g. flour, salt, sugar, ice) as well as equipment (e.g. a cooler, thermos).

loans.use: Purchase canteen equipment and supplies

loans.name: Taimalie

texts.en: Taimalie is 38 years old with six children she loves very much.  She has always spent a lot of time making clothes for her family and friends, and she noticed that locals were seeking her out to make and tailor clothes for them.  Taking the initiative to capitalize on this demand for her talents, Taimalie used an initial SPBD loan to set up a proper sewing business.  She can earn up to ST 150 (approximately USD 58) per day with her sewing; without this modest income, Taimalie couldn’t provide for the basic needs of her large family.  Taimalie is confident that she can grow her business yet further and is seeking an additional loan to make necessary repairs to her sewing machine and purchase some higher quality materials and equipment.

loans.use: machine repairs, sewing machine needles, scissors

loans.name: Vaimaila

texts.en: Vaimaila is 30 years old, and in an effort to support her family, she has started a small flea market stall.  Here she sells nuts, fruits, vegetables and coconut tree fibers.  Most of these items are grown or handmade by her and her husband.  She hopes to expand the products that she can offer the customers in her village, and is thus seeking a loan to purchase additional materials for making handicrafts and growing vegetables.  Vaimaila is passionate about becoming a small business owner and is putting all of her efforts into growing her flea market stall.  She feels that this is the best way for her and her husband to raise the standard of living for her family.

loans.use: Buy raw materials to make/grow goods for her flea market stall

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina tiene 51 años de edad, es una persona muy trabajadora, honesta y responsable, ella es casada y tiene dos hijos, su esposo es carpintero y hace diez años por cuestiones de enfermedad no podía trabajar y para cubrir las necesidades de la familia, Catalina empezó con la venta de cosméticos por recomendación de su hermana, poco a poco los clientes se incrementaron al igual que la demanda de sus productos, el esfuerzo de Catalina le llevo de ser vendedora a ser distribuidora de los productos.

Para surtir los pedidos de sus clientes Catalina necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 475 dólares que utilizará para otorgar un mejor servicio y permanecer en la preferencia de su clientela, ella ofrece pagar este crédito en un lapso de 5 a 10 meses. Tú puedes ser parte importante de sus logros, decídete a apoyarla.

Translated to English by Nuria Ruiz

Catalina is 51 years old. She is a hard working mom of two. Catalina's husband is a carpenter, ten years ago he got sick and was unable to work for some time. At that time Catalina was in charge of providing for the family and -following her sister advice- she started her business selling cosmetics. Little by little she grew her clientele and after some time she went from seller to distributor of cosmetic products.

She is asking for a loan of 475$ to be able to better serve her clientele. She will repay the loan in five to ten months. You can contribute to her achievement.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina tiene 36 años, esta casada y tiene tres hijos, de 14, 9 y 6 años. En el año 2000, la familia pasó por momentos difíciles por que los gastos se incrementaban por el nacimiento de su último hijo, Cristy inició con la venta de cosméticos, con la finalidad de ayudar a su esposo con los compromisos del hogar y de la educación de sus hijos, el gusto por la ventas la ha llevado a vender varios productos, a ganar más clientes y aumentar sus pedidos.

En estos momentos Cristy necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 750 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para cubrir las demandas de sus clientes y poder brindarles un buen servicio, ella ofrece retornar el crédito en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses. Conviértete en parte importante de sus logros, tú puedes ayudar a mejorar la vida de esta familia, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu apoyo.

Translated to English by Nuria Ruiz

Cristina is married and she has three kids 14, 9 and 6 years old. The family went through some hard times when their third child was born, the family expenses started were too high for the family income. In order to help her husband provide for the family Cristy started selling cosmetics. She turned out to be a great saleswoman and she was able to grew her clientele and volume quite fast.

At this time Cristy is asking for a loan of $750. She will use the loan to advanced purchases of inventory so she can better serve her clients. She will repay the loan in a 6 to 12 month interval. This family would greatly appreciate your help.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Mrs. Leticia H. has owned her tire shop for 1 year. “I am a single mother, and my business is my only income. I have a young man who helps me, since there are many things that I, as a woman, am not strong enough to do. I would like to purchase tires, an air compressor, and a hydraulic jack so that I can service my clients more quickly. I am asking for $1000.00 dollars for the purchase of tires, the air compressor, and the hydraulic jack.

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Leticia Hernández tiene una vulcanizadora desde hace 1 año.” Soy mamá soltera y mi negocio es mi único ingreso, tengo la ayuda de un joven ya que hay muchas cosas que por ser mujer no tengo la fuerza para hacerlas, me gustaría comprar llantas, un compresor y un gato hidráulico para atender más rápido a mis clientes”. Solicito $1,000.00 dlls para la compra de las llantas, el compresor y el gato hidráulico

loans.use: Purchase tires, an air compressor, and a hydraulic jack.

loans.name: Everardo

texts.en:
Mr. M. small convenience store which he aims to keep well stocked. "I'm in one of the city's newer neighborhoods and want to keep my neighbors happy so I'm asking for a $1,000 loan to increase the variety of my products."

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. M. cuenta con un pequeñoo negocio de abarrotes su idea principal del negocio es mantenerlo surtido. "Estoy en uno de los nuevos fraccionamientos de la ciudad y quisiera tener bien complacidos a todos mis vecinos así que solicito un préstamo de $1,000.00 dlls para comprar mas variedad de mercancía".

loans.use: To buy more products for his store

loans.name: Atake

texts.en:
Ms. Atake is single and the mother of one child. She has specialized in the preparation of a local beverage called “tchukutchu” for one year. (Tchukutchu is a traditional millet/sorghum-based drink.) She sells this two times a week and each preparation is completely sold out.

Ms. Atake is part of a HELP Africa solidarity group called “Solidarity,” which has collectively applied for a loan of $300. Each member of the group will receive a part of this loan and will be responsible for helping their fellow group members if they are delinquent or default.

loans.use: Increase millet and firewood stock

payments.comment: Thank you for helping Tchilalo . She was able  to pay  50 dollars as of today August 16 th. From now going she will be able to keep the ball runs because she understands beter the system  and HELP Africa put more staff  to help them in the system .Again thank you

Thak you . Your support was needed to make this big change on this woman's life 
Thank yoou

loans.name: María Concepción

texts.en:
Maria is a very nice person who lives in the western part of the city where she has a small store. "Please help me keep my store well stocked. I want to have a good convenience store and for my business to prosper. I need a loan of $1,200 to make my dream come true."

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña "Maria" es una persona muy linda ella habita en el poniente de la ciudad y ahí mismo tiene su tiendita. "Por favor necesito que me ayuden a surtir mi tiendita quisiera que mi negocio prosperara y llegar a tener una muy buena tienda de abarrotes para esto se requiere unas cantidad de $1,200.00 dlls y así cumplir mi sueño.

loans.use: Purchase canned goods and other convenience store items.

loans.name: Zénabou

texts.en:
Married with one child, Mrs. Zénabou started this business one year ago. She counts on introducing a new product in her business of wood charcoal, because according to her, wood charcoal is safer for children and family members in poor areas like ours. This wood charcoal is made in an environmentally-friendly manner, and is sought out for its economic savings, which helps establish an equal footing among citizens. With her business, Mrs. Zénabou must wait for a beneficiary two times more than the one before.

The total of her loan of $100 will go to the buying of firewood.

Mrs. Zénabou is part of a HELP Africa solidarity group of six women called “Second Association,” which has collectively applied for a loan of $600. Each member of the group will receive a part of this loan and will be responsible for helping their fellow group members if they are delinquent or default.

loans.use: Increase business activities

payments.comment: Thank you for helping Zenabou. She was able  to pay  50 dollars as of today August 16 th. From now going she will be able to keep the ball runs because she understands beter the system  and HELP Africa put more staff  to help them in the system .Again thank you

Thank you so much. Your help was needed to make the change on this woman's life.We  very much thank you for your support 
Thank you

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Mrs. K. is married and the mother of four children. She has been doing this business for five years. Her food supply consists mainly of bottles of tinned food, drinks, and milk products, which has a high demand in the area where she lives. This makes sales turn quickly, makes turnover of stock go fast, and makes her capable of repaying her debt before the same sort of delay which would make her stuck.

Mrs. K. is part of a HELP Africa solidarity group of four women. The solidarity group is called, “Shalom,” which has collectively applied for a loan of $800. Each member of the group will receive a part of this loan and will be responsible for helping their fellow group members if they are delinquent or default.

loans.use: Increase business activities

payments.comment: Thank you for helping pauline. She was able  to pay   50 dollars as of today August 16 th. From now going she will be able to keep the ball runs because she understands beter the system  and HELP Africa put more staff  to help them in the system .Again thank you
Many thanks  for helping me  and my family

Thak you . Your support was needed to make this big change on this woman's life 
Thank yoou
Thank you so much for your support. We look forward to continue supporting  their buinesses. Thank you

loans.name: Issaka

texts.en:
Married and the mother of four children, Mrs. Issaka has been of selling cloth for women's clothing for four years. According to her, her business will finally allow her to provide for the primary needs of her family, and she will not have to carry goods on her head and move around to sell her products, like most of her solidarity group members are doing. Because of a huge demand, she believes that she will be able to establish something more permanent and stable to avoid her up and down tours, which involve a lot of risks.

Mrs. Issaka is part of a HELP Africa solidarity group of four women. The solidarity group is called, “Essohana” which has collectively applied for a loan of $800. Each member of the group will receive a part of this loan and will be responsible for helping their fellow group members if they are delinquent or default.

loans.use: Increase business activities

payments.comment: Thank you for helping Nafissetou. She was able  to pay  20 dollars as of today August 16 th. From now going she will be able to keep the ball runs because she understands beter the system  and HELP Africa put more staff  to help them in the system .Again thank you

Thak you . Your support was needed to make this big change on this woman's life 
Thank yoou
Thank you for your pateince and support

loans.name: Faalua

texts.en: Faalua lives in the Samoan village of Lotofaga and is a mother of six and a grandmother of twelve.  Faalua began her taro plantation with funds from her first SPBD loan.  In her first planting, she raised 600 taro plants.  After two harvests of similar size, she found she had raised enough money to greatly increase her family’s income and help buy food for her many grandchildren.  Faalua’s family is very encouraging of her efforts, as it has not only made a valuable contribution to the family finances but has also been a source of satisfaction and pride for Faalua.  Faalua is committed to growing her plantation further.  Some of the income she saved from her initial two harvests went to buy additional taro seeds, and she is currently raising 1,200 taro plants.  She has set her goal even higher, and with her first SPBD fully repaid, Faalua is seeking an additional loan to purchase more seeds and buy supplies such as a wheelbarrow, knives and weed killer.

loans.use: Purchase taro seeds, wheelbarrow, knives, weed killer

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia and her husband run a handicrafts business in the Samoan village of Vaitele, and this business represents their family’s sole source of income.  In their home-based shop, Telesia and her husband make a variety of goods: jewelry, such as earrings, bracelets and rings, women’s and children’s clothing and coffins used in local burials.  Telesia and her husband are a talented couple, and via three previous SPBD loans, they have been able to leverage their talents and expand their business.  Now, the jewelry they make sells well at the local flea market, and they supply a large retail store with women’s and children’s clothes.  Additionally, the coffins that Telesia’s husband crafts are well designed and affordable for the locals, making this a profitable venture.  Telesia is seeking an additional loan to fund her family’s business.  The loan funds will be specifically used to build a workshop for Telesia and her husband and to purchase a sign advertising the sale of coffins.

loans.use: Build a workshop and purchase a sign

loans.name: Imeleta

texts.en: Imeleta, her husband and their two children live in a small Somoan village.  Prior to Imeleta joining SPBD, both Imeleta and her husband were unemployed and relied on the help of neighbors and nearby relatives for basic necessities such as food and water.  The women in Imeleta’s village encouraged her to join SPBD.  She did, and with her first loan, she was able to start up a small village store.  Since then, Imeleta and her family have seen small but steady gains in their standard of living.
