Also, Imeleta happily reports that the self-satisfaction she has gained as a result of her business endeavors has contributed to a marked improvement in her relations with her husband and children.  She remains grateful to the other village women who have continued to counsel her on running a small business.  Imeleta’s goal is to grow her business to bring in enough income for her to equip her home with water and electricity.  To achieve that goal, Imeleta is seeking further financing in order to expand her shop’s stock of goods.

loans.use: Purchase goods for her shop

loans.name: Leala

texts.en: Leala is a 45-year old woman with six grown children and numerous grandchildren.  She began a small vegetable farm six years ago to supply her flea market stand with fresh vegetables.  Her entrepreneurial success has enabled her to provide an improved standard of living and a good education for children.  Leala is now seeking to expand her vegetable farm and increase the variety and supply of goods that she brings to the flea market for her customers.  A loan to Leala would help her purchase the vegetable seeds and fertilizers she needs to expand her business.  Additionally, Leala takes great pride in her home, and she plans to use a portion of loan proceeds to effect some improvements to the roof and floor of her house and upgrade some of her home furnishings.

loans.use: :  Buy agricultural supplies and perform home improvements

loans.name: Penuafa

texts.en: Penuafa is 47-years old, married and lives in the small Samoan village of Siupapa.  She has three grown daughters and one 12-year old, adopted son.  Three years ago, as an attempt to raise her family’s standard of living and provide for her son’s school supplies and fees, Penuafa joined SPBD.  With the initial loan, Penuafa set up a pancake stand, and sold these Samoan delights in her local village.  She used additional SPBD financing to expand her business into making donuts and now has a steady stream of happy customers from the village primary school.  Penuafa has repaid all previous SPBD loans without missing a single payment.  She firmly believes that with hard work and an additional loan, she can expand her product line still further and concurrently make some much-needed improvements to her village home.  Penuafa’s longer-term goal is to set up a full-scale bakery shop.  SPBD is confident that she will continue to work hard and will eventually reach that goal.

loans.use: :  Purchase food supplies and make home improvements

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana is a 28-year old woman who must support her 4-year old daughter and 8-month old son, but prior to SPBD providing the loan financing to start her own business, she had little previous experience in earning her own income.  Susana’s mother was famous in the village for her flower gardens, and after her mother’s death, Susana decided to take over her mother’s garden and use it to develop a business that could provide for her and her children.  Susana used her initial SPBD loan to acquire her business license.  Since then, Susana has secured two large, regular customers – nearby beach resorts that cater to the tourists that flock to the white sand beaches in her region of Samoa.  Susana is anxious to secure another loan to further expand her business.  She is clearing space for additional flower gardens, and her dream is to someday grow her gardens into a full-scale nursery.

loans.use: gardening tools, fertilizers

loans.name: Ut

texts.en:
Ut is 60, her husband is 7 years older. They have two sons who have stopped attending school to work for somebody in Ho Chi Minh City. Their ages are 23 and 21.

Ut and her husband are so old that they aren't able to work as labourers. They operate a grocery store. Their income is $9 per person/month. They need a loan for $75 so that they can expand and increase the variety of food in their grocery store. They are going to repay monthly.

loans.use: To expand and increase the variety of food for their grocery store.

loans.name: Muzaffar

texts.en: Muzaffar is a father of three children. He is 36 years old. He started his business 10 years ago, after he lost his job at the factory. At the beginning, he was helping another entrepreneur. Over time, he collected enough money to rent his own place and sell food products. He often says that no matter what happens, people will always buy food. Therefore, he chose to sell food instead of another type of goods. The location of his business is in a main market of the town- “Panjshanbe”. It is a closed market, and he thinks he is lucky to have a comparably comfortable place of work. He will use the loan to expand his business and purchase a bigger volume of goods.

loans.use: Trade of food products

loans.name: Manzura

texts.en: Manzura is a mother of 3 children. She is new in business and has only 1 year of experience. Previously, she was a housewife and was at home with the children. Now her children are old enough to go to school, and the youngest is in kindergarten.  Her husband is very supportive; he is the one who gave her the initial capital to start her business.  For now, the goods that she sells are brought by wholesalers. In the future, when the turnover of her business is large enough, she will be traveling to wholesale markets to purchase goods herself. She will use the loan for goods for the coming season.

loans.use: New season goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is 27 years old and single. She is a returnee. During the war, she was in Iran where she trained to be a beautician and opened her own shop. When the situation got better in Afghanistan, she returned to Kabul with her family and opened a beauty salon there. She has a lot of customers, but lacks the finances to take full advantage of their business. She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase more cosmetics and salon supplies so she can expand what she offers in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and salon supplies

loans.name: Bimukaram

texts.en: Bimukaram is mother of 2. She has been in trade for over 18 years. She has changed the type of business she was engaged in, but she has been a seller for the last 18 years. Currently, she sells corn and other grains. Her clients are mostly people who use these products as fodder for their livestock and poultry.  She has several people who come out from rural areas to bring her the goods she sells. Sometimes she and her colleagues make these trips themselves. She hopes that her son will take over her business when he is old enough so that she might start something new. She will use the loan for her next trip for goods.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Manzuma

texts.en: After Manzuma lost her husband 10 years ago, she started working at the market with the help of a friend. At that time, she had two young children. She knew from her experience with children that she would be good at selling children's clothes and shoes. By now, Manzuma feels comfortable with her business, and she goes to the wholesale market herself. She would like to open a second business site where she would be selling women’s clothes. Her son will be helping her after school. She will invest the money she has collected and will add the new loan to open the second site.

loans.use: Opening new business site

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Jumah

texts.en: Jumah is 30 years old, and almost as many years experience in carpet weaving. He has one loam and has 6 students. He is requesting a loan of $600 so he can purchase another loam and materials which will enable him to produce more carpets and increase his income. His goal is to bring positive changes to his life and support his family economically. He also enjoys teaching his students to weave fine carpets so they can have a skill.

loans.use: To purchse yarn, color and other necessary materials

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.en: Gulnora is a mother of one child and got divorced several years ago. She had to move back to her parents' house and decided to earn her own money. It has been three years since she started working at the market. One day, she hopes to make enough money to get a University degree and have an apartment of her own. Gulnora is a hard-working person, and she believes that her business will help her to accomplish her goals. Her brother helps her in her business. Most of the time, he makes the trips to bring the goods for her to sell. She would like to use the loan to purchase more grain to sell.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Hosiyat

texts.en: Hosiyat has been managing her business for the last three years. Her sister asked her to join her in her business; however, for the last two years, Hosiyat has been working independently. Hosiyat is married and is the mother of 4 children. She knows that having a business means sometimes taking risks, but she has been very cautious so far. She is expanding her business gradually. She thinks having four children helps her in her work, because she knows exactly what type of seasonal clothing children need, and therefore what their parents would buy. She will use the next loan for summer-time shoes.

loans.use: Purchase of summer-time shoes

loans.name: Roya

texts.en: Roya is single and has 10 years experience in the tailoring business. She has many customers and also teaches 5 students. Usually her customers provide the fabric she uses to sew their clothes, and she is paid for her labor. She is requesting a loan of $300 so she can purchase an electric sewing machine, fabric and other sewing materials. Her dream is to create many styles of clothing that she can sell in the market. This will not only increase her income, but will also present her clothes making talent to the public.

loans.use: To purchase and electric sewing machine, fabric and other sewing materials

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: Mavluda started working at the market 6 years ago. She is married and has three children. She started with men’s underwear and socks. Over time, she expanded her business and now sells men’s clothes. Her goods are mainly brought from Kyrgystan. She considers the spring and end of summer to be the best time for her business. She gets the most profit from sales during this time. Mavluda also noticed that men today spend more money for their clothes than they did several years ago. She likes her job as she likes the interaction with people.  Summers are very hot in Tajikistan, and that’s why she wants to buy a large number of T-shirts to sell during the next couple of months.

loans.use: Purchase of men’s t-shirts

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Zebo

texts.en: Zebo is 34 years old. Her name means “beautiful,” and she thinks that’s why she is in the beauty business. She has a University degree, but she did not get a chance to work. She got married early and had a child. Later, she had two more kids and decided to work only after the children were old enough to go to school. At this point, it was quite late to start a career; therefore, Zebo started working at the market. She now has three years of experience in trade. She sells the goods that are brought by wholesalers. She has never gone to the wholesale market herself. In the future, she would like to add other types of goods for sale. She will use her loan to buy goods. Summer is a wedding season in Tajikistan, and new brides spend a lot of money for cosmetics. Zebo is sure she will have good profits this summer.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ahmad Shah

texts.en:
Ahmad Shah is 45 years old, and has 15 years experience in metal working. He has a metal shop and
10 students. They create metal windows, chairs, doors, etc. He is requesting a loan of $850 so he can purchase more materials and open a second metal shop. This will provide more income and work for himself and his students.

loans.use: To purchase materials for his metal shop

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira is 24 years old and lives with her nine-member family in District 13 of Kabul. She is single. Samira and her brother are in business together. She and three other sisters create flowers in their home, and her brother sells them at his shop in the main market place. He also does the marketing for the business.

She is on her 4th cycle loan from AFSG, and these loans have enabled her to grow her business. Now she is able to continue her studies that she missed during the Taliban years. She could not have done this without the help of the AFSG loan program. She is requesting another loan of $400 to further expand her business and improve her family's standard of living and education.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the brother of Samira. With some families in Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: To purchase color paper and plastic to make flowers

loans.name: Sok Sa

texts.en: Sok Sa R. is 51 years old and is married with 4 children.  Three of her daughters work in a garment factory and together make $150 per month. Her fourth daughter is a student, and helps her mother sew clothes when she is not at school.  Sok Sa R. will use this loan to buy a washing machine so that she can provide cleaning services to her customers.  She also plans to buy a motorbike for her children to drive so that she can spend more time at work.  In the future, she hopes to repair her house once she has saved enough money.

loans.use: To purchase a washing machine and a motorbike so her children can drive themselves to work

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Sok Sa Roeun has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Mrs. Beatrice O. had 6 months of training before she started her retail business in the year 2004. She is 60 years old, married, and has four children. According to Beatrice, US$400 will enable her to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of pure water

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Mrs. Dorcas O. is married and has four children. She was trained as a tailor in a notable fashion home in Nigeria. According to Dorcas herself, LAPO was a big help to her in the year 2002, when she was in need of money to upgrade her business. She is now asking for a loan of US$400 to further improve the business.

loans.use: To buy an additional sewing machine and sewing materials

loans.name: Chor

texts.en: Chor C. is 51 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children.  Her husband works as a soldier, 1 son is a construction worker, 1 daughter works in a garment factory, and two of her children are students and help with her business.  Mrs. Chor sells small bottles of gasoline on the side of the road for motorbikes.  She also runs a small booth of cell phones that people can stop and use.  Her average profit per day is about $3.  She plans on using this loan to buy more gasoline in order to increase her profit.  She also would like to buy some wood in order to build a small home.  In the future, she hopes to continue expanding her business so that she can pay for all of her children to go to school.

loans.use: To buy wood to build house and to buy gasoline for selling on the road.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S. P. is 29 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband (pictured here because she was working when we visited), and 2 small children.  She sells vegetables in the local market and can make about $4 per day.  Her husband drives a motor taxi and earns about $2 per day. She will use this loan to build a $500 home that she will rent out monthly.  She also plans on buying a new motor taxi for her husband so that he can earn more daily income.  She hopes to continue growing her vegetable business so that she can build a proper home for her and her family to live in.

loans.use: To build a home to rent out and to buy a motor taxi for her husband

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Abiodun

texts.en: A woman of age 58, Abiodun is married and has six children. She lives in the semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State of Nigeria, where she started her own retail business in the year 1996. She specializes in the sale of drinks. According to Abiodun, a loan of US$625 would greatly help her in expanding the business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Sai Sam

texts.en: Sai Sam E. is 38 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 3 children.  She works at home as a tailor and earns about $2.50 per day.  Her husband works as a motor taxi driver and makes an average of $4 per day.  This income allows Sai Sam E. and her husband to pay for their children to go to school.  She will use this loan to build a house that she will rent out monthly in order to increase her family's income.  She also has plans to purchase a stall in the local market where she will sell coffee.  In the future, Sai Sam E. wants to build more homes for rental so that she can earn enough money to send all 3 of her children to University.

loans.use: To build a house for monthly rental

loans.name: Baheja

texts.en:
Baheja D/O A. Najib lives in District 6 of Kabul City. She is married to A. Alem and has nine family members. She and her son operate a grocery store. They buy grocery goods from the main market in Kabul and sell them in their shop. Baheja has finished her 1st cycle loan and now wants to begin a 2nd cycle. When they first opened their shop, they weren't able to offer much to their customers. Thanks to the AFSG loan program, they were able to increase their stock and their income. Now Baheja is requesting a loan of $225 so she can continue to grow her business.

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase rice, ghee, tea, sugar, and other foodstuffs

loans.name: Sum Kim

texts.en: Sun Kim H. is 41 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with his wife and 2 children.  He works as a mechanic near his home, and can earn $10 per day fixing motorbikes.  He will use this loan to purchase more tools in order to grow his shop, as well as to build a house.  He plans on renting the house to nearby garment factory workers and expects that the rental income will help his family to live more comfortably.  In the future, he hopes to continue building houses for local workers to rent.

loans.use: To purchase tools for fixing motorbikes and to build a house to rent to garment factory workers

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Mrs. Bridget A. is 34 years old, married, with four children. She first obtained a loan from LAPO in the year 2003. Now Bridget plans to further increase the stock of provisions in her store if granted a loan of US$400.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods for sale

loans.name: Omonigho

texts.en: Mrs. Omonigho E. is 25 years old. She obtained training as a nurse in a notable school of nursing in Nigeria. According to Omonigho herself, LAPO came to her aid in 2005 when she was in need of money to open up a medical store. If given a loan of US$400, she will further expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Sout

texts.en: Sout S. is 29 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their daughter, who attends school.  Sout owns a small grocery store and earns about $2.50 per day.  Her husband drives a motor taxi and can earn around $4 per day.  Sout S. will use this loan to buy more groceries for her store and to build a simple home for her family.  As her grocery business continues to expand, she would like to build a house to rent out in order to increase her monthly income.

loans.use: To buy grocery products for her store and to build a simple home.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Sout Sovorn has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand the grocery store and improve his farm so that they can save some money to buy a small home.

loans.name: Mercy O.

texts.en: A woman of age 38, Mercy O. is married and has four children. She lives in the semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State of Nigeria, where she started her business in the year 1998. Mercy O. specializes in the sale of drugs. She believes that a loan of US$400 will be a good help to her in expanding the business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Osarumwense

texts.en: 35 years old, Mrs. Osarumwense O. learnt trade on selling of food items for 2 years before she started her own business in the year 1996. She is married with two (2) children and lived in Benin City, Edo State of Nigeria. According to her if the amount $250 get to her, she will be able to expand her business

loans.use: To buy more goods for sales

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is 54 years and has three (3) children. HEr business is the sale of provisions to the public. She started  her business 4 years ago. She is seeking a loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for sales

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth O. is 49 years old with five (5) children. She sells cooked food for the community. She needs a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea S. is 57 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband (pictured here) and their 6 children.  The family runs a small barbershop where the husband makes $10 per day, and 4 children, who are also barbers, make $20 per day combined.  Chea S.'s 2 other children attend school.  This loan will be used to build a small house for garment factory workers to rent.  Once she generates enough income from the rental house, she plans on expanding the barber shop as well as building a proper house for her family to live in.

loans.use: To build a house to rent to garment factory workers.

loans.name: Khamid

texts.en:
When Khamid started his business, he traded in the Istaravshan clothing market. He had a small assortment of clothing and earned about $100 per month. Khamid wanted to expand his assortment of goods, increase his sales, and improve his business conditions.

To expand his assortment of goods and improve his working conditions, he needed funds. Starting in November 2003, he became a client of MicroInvest. Khamid's first loan was $100. He started to increase his credit, expand his assortment, increase the turnover of goods, and hire a saleswoman. By now, he has enough capital to make trips to the wholesale market himself. He would like to use the next loan for the trip to Karasuu (Uzbekistan) for goods. With the development of his business, Khamid was able to increase his contribution to the family expenses and improve his living conditions.

loans.use: Trip for goods

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira D/O Mohammad Esa was born in 1989 and lives in District 6 of Kabul City. She is single and shares a tailoring business with her brother who runs a tailoring shop in a market of Kabul City. At the start of their business, they worked in their home. After taking a first cycle loan from AFSG, they were able to open a shop in the market (a better business location) and expand their business. Now she is ready to begin the 2nd loan cycle so she can purchase more materials, make more clothes and earn better income for her big family.

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase fabrics, threads, needles, buttons, etc

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Mr. Seang S. is 71 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with his only daughter.  His wife recently passed away, so now he and his daughter rely heavily on each other for their livelihood.  Seang S. produces wine and earns about $5 per day.  He has been saving his money and plans to combine those savings with the loan to buy a hair salon for his daughter.  He feels that his daughter will succeed as a hair stylist and as he grows older she will be able to support him.  In the future, he plans on continuing to invest in his daughter's shop so that she will succeed.

loans.use: To purchase hair styling shop for his daughter
