loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.en: Shahnoza has been engaged in trade for 4 years. When she decided to start her own business, she borrowed $100 from her relatives. Shahnoza is a mother of 2 children. Although she has a University degree, the small salary at her previous job forced her to leave and start working at the market. At this point, her business has grown, and she has a much higher amount of turnover. Since she works at an open-air market, her main goal is to improve her working conditions. She would like to use the next loan to buy construction materials and repair the roof of her business site with the help of her husband.  She will probably spend about $300 for the repairs and the rest to buy goods.

loans.use: Improving working conditions.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Eromosele

texts.en: Mrs. Eromosele Asijehas been a LAPO client of for some time. She cherishes talking about LAPO loan and the poor in Nigeria. She is married with two (2) children. She hopes to expand her soft drink business with the use of this loan.

loans.use: To buy more drinks

loans.name: Zebo

texts.en: Zebo is married and has two children. Her main goal is for her children to get University degrees. Zebo has been in trade for over 5 years. At the beginning, she had a very small place she was renting at an open-air market. Now she is renting part of a store. She sells food products. She decided to give her previous place at the open-air market to her son, who is helping her in their business. Now these two places bring them higher income. Her son works only after his classes at school. He is a high-school student. The next loan will be used to buy goods for both business sites.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Mrs. Patience A. is married with five (5) children. She is 50 years old andn has been a LAPO client for the past 4 years. She is delighted in engaging in sales of provision and drinks. She is optimistic that her business will improve if she is loaned the sum of $250.

loans.use: To buy more provisions

loans.name: Zulfira

texts.en:
After graduating from high-school, Zulfira’s family did not have enough money for her to study at University. She got married early. She is mother of 6 children, and she is sure her children will get a good education. Zulfira and her husband are saving to make this happen.

Zulfira has over 7 years of experience in trade. To start her business, she borrowed $200 from her neighbor who was also working at the market. Her neighbor helped Zulfira a lot. When she started trading, she started with clothes for little kids and infants. Over time, she added men’s clothes into her assortment of goods. She would like to add towels and bed linens to her business, as she has noticed that demand is high for these goods. For this, she needs a loan of $1000.

loans.use: New assortment of goods – bed linen

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Neit

texts.en: Neit U. is 64 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with his wife and their 6 children.  Neit and his wife run a small store on the side of the street selling fresh water, gasoline, and cigarettes.  They earn aboU. $3 per day in this business.  One of their children is a local school teacher and adds $50 per month to the family's income.  Neit U. will use this loan to purchase more fresh water and gasoline for his store.  As his business grows, he would like to move his business indoors where he can sell more grocery items and earn more income.  He plans on working hard so that all of his children will have the chance to finish high school.

loans.use: To buy fresh water, gasoline, and cigarettes to sell on the roadside

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mukarram

texts.en: Mukarram started her business 7 years ago. She received her first loan in April 2005. She is one of the successful clients of MicroInvest. She works at the central market of Zafarabad. Her teenage children help her in her business. Mukarram has about $2000 in her sales turnover. She buys her goods from the Istaravshan wholesale market, which is one hour away from her town. Since she started her business, the living conditions of her family have improved. She was able to buy home equipment and make repairs in their house. She often recommends receiving loans to her colleagues at the market. She and several entrepreneurs who work nearby would like to improve the condition of their storage house in the market. Each of them will invest their share of money to do this.

loans.use: Improving conditions for storage of goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Salomat

texts.en:
Salomat is a member of the group “Humo”. She was one of the creators of the group. She needed money for her business but did not have collateral, so she helped create a solidarity group in order to receive a loan from MicroInvest as a solution for her business. Since 2005, she has been receiving loans from MicroInvest. All of the members of her group are satisfied with that. They never have had difficulties with repayment.

Salomat started her business over 10 years ago. She sells various home appliances, goods for the house, and office supplies. Her children help her in the business. She has $2100 in sales turnover. She makes the trips to the wholesale market herself. Her goal is to improve the quality of the goods sold. That means she will have to buy more expensive goods, but she thinks they will be in demand because of quality. She will use the next loan for the trip to the wholesale market.

loans.use: Trade of home appliances

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
Sharifa D/O Burhan Din was born in 1963 and lives in District 6 of Kabul City. She is married and has five family members. She and her husband have a grocery and vegetable shop. In the beginning, her husband just sold vegetables, and it was difficult to meet their daily expenses. When Sharifa finished her first loan cycle, they were able to open a grocery store, buy groceries from the main market in Kabul and sell them at their shop. This made them better able to meet expenses. Now Sharifa is ready to begin her second loan cycle so they can continue to improve their business and meet the needs of their family.

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, flour, tea, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Huo

texts.en: Huo P. is 41 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 2 children.  Her husband is a police officer and earns $4 per day.  Her 2 young children are currently attending school.  Huo P. runs a small grocery store and also buys rice in bulk to sell to local restaurants for retail.  She will use this loan to buy more groceries, as her business is doing very well.  She is confident that she will be able to sell these extra products, earn extra income, and make her living standard better.  In the future, she wants to continue growing her business so that she can send her children to University and so that she can make her home bigger and more beautiful.

loans.use: To buy grocery products

loans.name: Sim Srey

texts.en: Sim Srey T. is 40 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband, their 3 children, and 2 of her nephews.  Her husband is a driver for a private company and earns $11 per day.  Sim Srey T. is a tailor and earns $4 per day.  With this loan, she will purchase clothes for her stock and buy a sewing machine so that she can increase her output.  She also has plans to hire a second worker to increase her profit.  In the future, she wants to continuing growing her business by hiring more workers.  As she earns more money, she hopes to save enough to send her 3 children to University.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for her stock and to buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Maghfor

texts.en:
Maghfor D/O M. Anwar was born in 1956 and lives in District 6 of Kabul City. She and her son run a property dealer shop which helps people find homes, cars, buildings, etc. to rent or buy. She is in her first loan cycle with AFSG and will use this money to purchase furniture for their business. Maghfor is illiterate because she wasn't able to take on studies during the wars. She wishes to help her family financially, and she is grateful the AFSG loan program that is making it possible for she and her son to grow their business.

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase furniture for her shop

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: A 53 year woman, Dorcas A., a LAPO client of distinction. She cherishes talking about LAPO loan and the poor in Nigeria. She is married with three (3) children and she hopes to use this loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more snacks and drinks

loans.name: Nkechi

texts.en: "I changed to this business ten (10) years ago and I have no cause to regret it. I am 27 years old. My numerous customers always give me satisfaction," says Mrs. Nkechi P. E.. She needs the above amount to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more drugs and provisions

loans.name: Sahnaz

texts.en: Sahnaz is 44 years old and lives with four family members in Kabul City. Her husband has five years experience repairing bicycles and motor bikes. Sahnaz is requesting a loan so her husband can buy bicycle parts and other materials for his shop. This loan will help him rebuild his shop and satisfy customer demand. It will also help their family meet their living expenses and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase bicycle parts

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz D/O S. Ahmad Shah lives in District 13 of Kabul City. She is married and has four family members. She and her son have a fresh fruit cart. In her first loan cycle, she bought fruits for her son to sell from the cart so they could earn money for their family's daily needs. She plans to continue in the loan program so she can establish a shop for her son which will allow more room for goods and increase their sales. She thanks AFSG for providing loan opportunities to her.

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase fresh fruit

loans.name: Enoma

texts.en: Mrs. Enoma A. is married with three (3) children. She is 36 years old, a LAPO client for the past 3 years. She is happily engaged in sales of provision and drinks. She is optimistic that she can expand her business with a loan $500.

loans.use: To buy more drinks

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: "LAPO has shine light to my family," says Mrs. Joseph U.. She hailz from Edo State, Nigeria.  She is married with five (5) children. She sells cooked food to the community and wishes to expand her business with a loan in the above amount.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Farzana

texts.en:
Farzana D/O S. Mohammad Ali lives in District 13 of Kabul City. She is married to Khalil-u-Rahman and has four Family members. She and her husband operate a vegetable cart. Beginning this business was difficult, because they didn't have enough capital. But thanks to the AFSG loan process, Farzana was able to participate in her first loan cycle which enabled her to buy enough produce to develop the business. Now she has finished her 1st loan cycle and she wishes to begin her 2nd loan cycle. She plans to open her own shop in the future.

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To buy potatoes, onions and other vegetables

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en: Mr. Benjamin I.. Hails from Edo State, Nigeriaand is married with two (2) children. He sells cooked food to the community and wishes to expand his business with a loan in the above amount.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Zakira

texts.en:
Zakira and her husband have a tailoring business. She is requesting a loan so they can buy new machines and sewing supplies, so they can rebuild their lives and have a better future. She is thankful for the loan programs that help poor people create better lives for themselves.

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase materials for a tailoring shop

loans.name: Maria’S

texts.en: Mrs. Maria’s O. is a 42 years old woman. She is happily married with five (5) children. She is delightedly in engaging in sales of drugs. She is optimistic that she can expand her business if loaned the sum of $400.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for sales

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima D/O Hussain A. was born in 1963. She is married and lives in District 6 of Kabul City. She is an uneducated Women and with four family members. She help her son, who has a general store. During the wars, her financial situation really got bad, and her children had to quit going to school. After the wars she decided to change her life by starting a business. That was when she helped her son start a grocery store. Due to the success of her participation in the loan program, their family income is good and her children can go back to school. She has finished her 1st cycle and wishes to take the 2nd cycle loan so they can be more secure financially.  

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks, milk, powder, and other foodstuffs

loans.name: Marshal

texts.en: Mr. Marshal N.. Hails from a semi-rural area in Edo State, Nigeria. He is married with eight (8) children. He deals in the sales of cooking material to the community and promises to expand his business with the above amount.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Chab

texts.en: Chab K. is 54 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 5 children.  Her husband is a construction worker and earns $3 per day.  Two of her children are mechanics, and together they make $100 per month.  One of her daughters is a garment factory worker and earns $50 per month.  Chab K. grows and sells vegetables at the market, and she will use this loan to buy 1 hectare of land in order to grow more crops.  As her income grows, she plans on buying more land and eventually upgrade her home so that it will be comfortable for her family to live in.

loans.use: To buy 1 hectare of land to grow crops

loans.name: Nasima

texts.en: Nasima is 40 years old and married with four children. She has four years experience operating her food store, which her son helps her run. She has learned to manage the cash flow, organize the goods, and handle cleaning, packaging and selling her wares. She is excited to begin her first loan cycle so she can restock her store and purchase new items that customers are asking for. She is a hard working woman.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her food store

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en: Mrs. Dorah E. is a 42 years old woman. She is delightedly in engaged in sales of mini- provision. She is optimistic that she can improve her business if given a loan in the sum of $400.

loans.use: sales of mini- provision

loans.name: Progress

texts.en: "I changed to this business four (4) years ago and I have no cause to regret it. Though I am 39 years old; my numerous customers always give me satisfaction", says Mrs. progress O.. She needs the above amount to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more provision for sales

loans.name: Pashton

texts.en: Pashton is a mother of eight children and lives in Kabul City. She has a small retail shop in her alley and sells gas, fuel, Pepsi, baskets, powders, and other popular items. She works part-time with her son who is student in school. She was able to study up to the 6th grade before she left school, and this enables her to work outside the home. She is requesting a loan so she can enlarge her shop and purchase more goods to sell. This will enable her to better provide for her family.

loans.use: To enlarge her shop and purchase more goods

loans.name: Ba

texts.en: Both Ba and her husband are 59. They live with their son who has mental illness. Ba’s activity is to raise fish. Ba has a lake of 80 square meters for raising fish. Ba's income, which comes from raising fish, is only $7 per person/month. Now, Ba wants a loan of $75 to expand her fish farm. Ba is going to repay monthly.

loans.use: To raise fish.

loans.name: Khorshid

texts.en:
Khorshid D/O M. D. was born in 1941 and lives in District 13 of Kabul City. She is married and has four family members. She and her husband own a fresh fruit cart. She was married young, wasn't able to complete her education, and has faced a lot of financial problems. To overcome these problems, she decided to take part in her husband's business. This wasn't easy, as they didn't have the capital they needed to expand their sales. Then she heard about the loan programs. Her first loan enabled her to supply more customers. She has finished her 1st loan cycle, and wishes to participate in the 2nd cycle. Khorshid has learned that if she is able to purchase more fruit, she will have more sales and increase her income. 

***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase apples, melons, and other fruits

loans.name: Zubaida

texts.en: Zubaida is 45 years old, married, and has five years experience selling foodstuffs. Her son helps her buy and sell her stocks of food. She manages the cash, organization, cleaning, and packaging of the goods. She is requesting a loan so that she can offer more products to her customers. Participating in the loan program will enable her to increase her sales and earn more money to support her family's needs.

loans.use: To increase her stock of foodstuffs and other items

loans.name: Noor Mohammad

texts.en:
Noor M. supports his family by operating a general store shop in the market. During the war he had a cosmetics cart, but materials were in short supply and his sales were small. He participated in the loan program so he could open a general store and earn more income for his family. With his first loan, he stocked his shop with goods his customers need, and his business did better. Now he is requesting another loan so he can further expand his his stock and better provide for his family.
He is very happy with the loan process and gives thanks to those who established these programs that help people like him improve their lives.

loans.use: Buying goods

loans.name: Amenzee

texts.en: Mrs. Amenzee I. is a 46 years old woman who has five (5) children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer. She solicits for the above amount to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve on her business

loans.name: Abdullo

texts.en: Abdullo is a photographer with 20 years of experience. Abdullo also acts as teacher for those who would like to learn making professional photos. His two sons work together with him. When he applied for the first loan last year, he had only 3 cameras of the old type. Since then, he was able to change the equipment in his shop; he bought a new computer, 2 digital cameras, and a printer. The quality of the photos that he was printing improved, and he increased his profit. He would like to use the next loan to buy one more digital camera and one more printer.

loans.use: Improving working conditions

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Badal

texts.en: Badal is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. He is married and has 6 children. He started his business in 1995, and borrowed four Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $2000. Now he is willing to borrow $1000 to increase the variety of goods in his family business. (That's his wife in the picture).

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Pari Gul

texts.en:
Pari gul is married and has six children. Her husband has a retail shop. She helps with purchasing, cleaning and packaging food items. She also manages the cash. She is requesting a loan so they can purchase more food items and increase their sales. They work very hard to meet their family's needs, and this loan will enable them to improve their income and standard of living.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: buying food item

loans.name: Ortikboi

texts.en:
M. Ortikboi is a coordinator of the group “Farz”. He created this group when he decided to apply for loans. The group was founded on 18 August, 2005. Since then, Mr. M. has been an active participant of MicroInvest microcredit program.

Mr. M. is engaged in the trade of food products in the Zafarabad district. At the beginning, his sales turnover made $150. At the present time, it is about $800. Due to the organizational skills of Mr. M., the group paid off the loan on time. Mr. M. purchases the goods at wholesale from Zafarabad market and re-sells them in the shop by retail. He wants to take a loan and bring goods from Khujand, Istaravshan and other countries. In the future, Mr. M. wants to expand his business and open a trade outlet / grocery store.

loans.use: Trip to wholesale market

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet I. is a 36 year old woman with five children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, and sells Ogbolo. She is requesting 400 USD to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zahgilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has five children. She started her business in 1997, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totalin $600. Now she wants to borrow $650.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Zeynab

texts.en: Zeynab is an Internally Displaced Person from the Aremenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has five children. She started her business in 1995, and borrowed two Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $650. Now she wants to borrow $650.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Maleyka

texts.en: Maleyka is an Internally Displace Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has four children. She started her business in 1995. Maleyka plans to borrow $300 from Normicro Baku branch to increase her variety of goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Zohra

texts.en:
Zohra is 28 years old and lives in District 6 in Kabul City in a household of seven. Her father had lots of financial problems, so she is participating  in the loan program so she and her father can overcome these problems. The loan program enables them to open a business selling foodstuffs, and has made her father very happy with the help from his daughter. Zohra is requesting a loan to improve this business and her family's lives. She is grateful that these loan programs have been established and are so successful at helping poor people raise their standards of living. 


***Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband or relative of the female entrepreneur.  In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.***

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs

loans.name: Seminariya

texts.en: Seminariya is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has four children. She started her business in 1994, and borrowed 7 Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $5200. Now she wants to borrow $2000.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Akporuru

texts.en: Akporuru E. lives in Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. She is 35 years old and married with three children. She started her business in the year 2004. She needs the loan for her business expansion.

loans.use: To improve on her business

loans.name: Omohimoria

texts.en: Mr. Omohimoria G. hails from Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. He is married with five children. He deals with the sales & repair of refrigerators for the community and promises to expand his business with the loan.

loans.use: To improve on the business

loans.name: Tamella

texts.en: Tamella is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armeniann-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has a child. She started her business in 1994, and borrowed four Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $2000. Now she wants to borrow $1000 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand volume of business

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Mrs. Alice A. is a 52 year old woman with five children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She requests the above loan amount to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve on the business

loans.name: Mais

texts.en: Mais is an Internally Diplaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. Married, he has three children. He started his business in 1994, and borrowed four Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $2000. Now he wants to borrow $900 to increase the variety of goods in his shop.

loans.use: To in increase variety of goods

loans.name: Ebi

texts.en: Mrs. Ebi S. had 6 months of training before she started up her business in the year 2004. She is 42 years old and married with three children. She requests a loan of USD 550 to expand her business.

loans.use: To improve on her business

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Mrs. Patience E. is 47 years old and lives in the urban area of Benin City in Edo State, Nigeria. She opened her own business in 1999. She is happily married with five children. She needs a loan of USD400 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Gulnisa

texts.en: Gulnisa is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has two children. She started her business in 1996, and borrowed four Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $2000. Now she wants to borrow $1000 to buy new equipment for her beauty salon.

loans.use: To buy new equipment for her beauty salon

loans.name: Zilgai

texts.en: Zilgai S/O Rajab Khan was born in 1970 and lives in District 9 of Kabul City. He is married and has nine family members. He was in high school when the war broke out and that caused him to quit his studies. Zilgai has finished the group loan process and now wants to take an individual loan so he can purchase the materials he needs to make his business better. The loan program has enabled him to buy a used wood-cutting machine, which let him build items more quickly. Now he is requesting a loan to purchase more equipment and wood to further develop his business.

loans.use: To purchase wood, wood cutting machine and other carpentry items

loans.name: Edebor

texts.en: "LAPO has brought joy and peace to my family," says Mrs. Edebor A.. She hails from the ancient city of Benin in the Edo State of Nigeria. She sells artwork to the public and requests a loan of USD250 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more artwork to sell

loans.name: Ulkar

texts.en: Ulkar is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993. Married, she has three children. She started her business in 1995, and borrowed five Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $1800. Now she wants to borrow $700 to increase the variety of goods in her shop.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Abela

texts.en: Mrs. Abela J. is 35 years old and lives in the urban area of Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. She opened her own business in 2002. She is happily married with two children. She plans to use her loan of USD350 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more kinds of drinks

loans.name: Eldar

texts.en: Eldar is an Internally Displaced Person from the Armenian-occupied Zangilan district of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993. Married, he has two children. He started his business in 1995, and borrowed five Normicro loans from Baku branch totaling $3000. Now he wants to borrow $1200 to increase the variety of goods in his shop.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Fotima

texts.en: After she was divorced from her husband, B. Fotima remained with her two children. She started working in the market and first had sales turnover that was hardly enough to purchase one bag of goods.  She now has over 10 years of experience in trade. She constantly developed her business from her profits. In the course of time, her business increased. When Fotima learned about the microcredit program of MicroInvest, she decided to take a loan and joined one of the solidarity groups.  Members of the group were also businesswomen like she was. The first loan was 80 dollars, and she spent it for an assortment of goods as she did before. As her work experience and credit increased, she increased the size of the loan. Currently, she has applied for $500 dollars. Since she started receiving loans, the assortment of goods that she sells has increased twice.  She will use the next loan to improve the condition of her place in the market and order shelves for her goods.

loans.use: Improving business site

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: "I changed to this business two years ago and I have no cause to regret it. I am 38 years old, married with three children; my numerous customers alway give me satisfaction," says Mrs. Mabel I.. She will use her loan of USD400 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for sales

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is 37 years old and married with three children. She lives in semi-urban area of Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. She started her business in 2004. She specializes in the sales of still water and bedspreads. Florence will use her USD400 loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Khwaja Mohammad

texts.en: Khwaja Mohammad S/O A. Hakim lives is District 15 of Kabul and is married. He runs a shop where he sells blankets and shoes. He buys blankets from Pakistani traders and sells them at the market. His business did not start well because he had little money, and so had few items to sell, therefore less customers. He heard about the AFSG loan program from a friend and decided to participate so he can develop his business. He is requesting a loan so he can increase his stock and reach more customers. This will improve his business and help him develop more trade.

loans.use: To purchase shoes and blankets

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Mrs. Kate A. is 46 years old and married with five children. She has been a LAPO client for over 5 years. She lives in Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. She wishes for a loan of USD400 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for sales

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: "Thanks to LAPO," says Mrs. Florence A.. She is 45 years old and married with five children. She has been a LAPO client for over 5 years. She lives in Benin City in Nigeria. Mrs. A. will use her loan of USD250 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Mrs. Grace O. is 65 years old with five children. She lives in Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. She intends to use her loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve on the business

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: "LAPO has shine light to my family," says Mrs. Sandra I.. She hails from the Edo State of Nigeria and is married with three children. She sells provisions and recharge cards to the community and wants to expand her business using her loan.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Mrs. Victoria O. is a 47-year-old woman. She is happily married with six children. She is delighted in engaging in the sale of food items, and is optimistic that her business will improve with the help of her USD400 loan.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell

loans.name: Diep

texts.en:
Diep is 41. Diep’s husband is 42. They have 5 children aged 15, 13, 13, 7, and 1. The eldest daughter stopped going to school to work as a labourer in Ho Chi Minh City. The three middle children are students.

Diep and her husband have to work hard growing sugarcane, and raising pigs and fish to support their children. Their income is only $6 per person/month. Because they must support their children, they don’t have enough capital to invest in growing the sugarcane trees. They need a loan of $75 from the Kiva programme to invest in their sugarcane field. They are going to repay monthly.

loans.use: To invest in growing sugar-cane.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mrs Helen O. is 41 years old. She has been a LAPO client for over 7 years. She lives in Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. She will use her USD500 loan to purchase more provisions and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Mrs. Anna O. is 60 years old and married with four children. She lives in a semi-urban area in Benin City in the Edo State of Nigeria. A dedicated client of LAPO who specializes in the sales of food ingredients, Mrs. O. wishes to use her USD400 loan to expand her market.

loans.use: To buy more food ingredients to sell

loans.name: Afi Dede

texts.en: Afi K. lives in Nkurankan, Ghana. She works with agricultural produce such as yams, cassava, plantain and smoked fish. She has four children in her care. To raise enough income to enable her to take care of them, she is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva, through Kraban Support Foundation.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is a school drop-out and a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She has tried to start a business selling yam. However, she does not have enough capital to keep her in business. Therefore, she is seeking a loan of US$700 from Kiva .

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence sells garri, a product from cassava dough. She lives in a school-going community where she sells to the public and the students. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She is seeking for a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited several times from the organization. She sells yams in her locality. She wants to expand her business and is therefore seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Margrete

texts.en: Margie is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has benefited several times from the organization. She sells bread and fried fish in her locality. She wants to expand her business and is therefore seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mamle

texts.en: Mamle has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has taken several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She makes beads for the local and foreign markets. She is seeking a loan of US$900.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: The

texts.en:
The is 39; her husband is 37. They live with two sons wH. are students at high school. Their activities include both growing rice and selling a variety of fruits and vegetables on rivers. Selling on boats is a very popular activity in the Cuu Long delta.

Recently, a disease-spreading insect has affected rice crops, so their rice production is only enough for them to eat. Now, their focus in selling on the boat. They hope to get a loan for $75 so that she can increase the variety of fruits and vegetables to sell on the boat. They promise to repay monthly.

loans.use: To increase the variety of fruits and vegetables to sell on the boat.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She operates a drinking spot. She is seeking a loan of US$750.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She sells maize to her customers. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Leonid

texts.en:
Leonid offers vehicle repair services. He has very skillful hands and can fix any auto problem. He also restores used cars and sells them at exceptional prices. Presently, his gross revenue per month is about $4,000 – $6,000, and his monthly net profit amounts to $1,400.

Leonid is a very patient and professional man. He has partnered with “Nadiya Ukraine” since 2003 and has used previous loans for business expansion. He has been able to purchase new equipment and construct a big garage which he uses for his repair shop and as a paint booth. The new equipment and garage facility have helped him repair and sell more vehicles at reasonable prices.

Leonid is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase some additional equipment to use in straightening, grinding, puttying, and painting cars as well as to do engine mechanical work and all other types of repairs. Leonid believes that good quality equipment will help him provide excellent repair service to his customers and further increase his ability to restore and sell used cars.

В Леоніда є власна автомайстерня. Він дуже талановитий, може полагодити будь-яку проблему. Він також займається відновленням автомобілів, а потім продає їх за помірними цінами. Зараз його щомісячний валовий дохід складає приблизно 4000 – 6000 доларів, чистий прибуток складає 1400 доларів. Леонід – дуже терплячий, він справжній професіонал. Він співпрацює з „Надією України” вже з 2003 року, усі попередні позики використовував для розширення власного бізнесу. Леонід придбав нове обладнання та відбудував великий гараж, який зараз використовує в якості майстерні, де ремонтує та красить автомобілі. Нове облаштування та гаражне приміщення допомогли йому відновити та продати за помірними цінами багато автомобілів. Леонід просить про позику в 800 доларів для того, щоб придбати додаткове обладнання для рихтування, шпаклювання та відновлення панелей автомобілів, а також для механічного ремонту двигунів, тощо. Леонід вважає, що якісне обладнання допоможе йому забезпечити чудове обслуговування покупців і він зможе надалі відновлювати та продавати старі автомобілі.

loans.use: To purchase tools for car repair

loans.name: María Luisa

texts.en:
Mrs. G. and her daughter run a beauty salon located in their home, having built a room just for their business. They only have basic equipment and need other kinds of tools to be able to provide all kinds of services. "My daughter and I have brought about the salon but our customers ask for specialized treatments which we don't always have the tools to do, which is why we need a loan of $1,200."

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. G. y su hija manejan una estética, la tienen ubicada en su vivienda, construyeron un cuarto especialmente para su negocio, solo cuentan con el equipo primario requieren de otra clase de equipo para la realización de todo tipo de trabajos. "Entre mi hija y yo hemos sacado adelante la estética solo que nuestros clientes nos piden trabajos especiales y en ocasiones no contamos con las herramientas necesarias para llevarlo acabo, necesitamos $ 1,200.00 dlls".

loans.use: Buy more advanced equipment/ appliances for their salon.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana T. has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She sells toilet soaps. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her sales.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is married and has one grown daughter. For a while she worked as a trolley-bus controller selling tickets to passengers. She also worked part-time as a market vendor. However, Galina wanted to be self-employed, so six years ago she decided to start her own business. Today she has four market vending facilities – two selling dishware sets and ceramics, and two locations selling clothing and shoes. She has hired several employees who help her with sales.

Galina realizes that lending services have been the engine pushing her business forward. The seventeen loans she has received and repaid from “Nadiya Ukraine” have helped her business grow. With financial assistance Galina was able to purchase two more vending facilities and hire two people to work for her. Currently, she has about $8,000 in inventory. Her monthly gross revenue amounts to $2,000.

Galina has requested a loan of $1,200 to open her fifth vending facility and start selling dishware and ceramic goods in a new location. She is planning to buy tableware, dinnerware and porcelain sets at wholesale prices that she can re-sell in her new kiosk. Galina is hoping that the expansion of her trade will help her meet high demand for dishware and boost her sales.

Галина – одружена, в неї є доросла дочка. Певний час вона працювала контролером в тролейбусі. Потім змінила місце роботи, почала працювати на ринку реалізатором. Проте, Галина хотіла працювати на себе. Отже, 6 років тому вона вирішила почати власну справу. Зараз в неї 4 торгові точки: два кіоски з продажу посуду та кераміки, два – з продажу одягу та взуття. В роботі Галині допомагають декілька реалізаторів. Галина розуміє, що кредитні послуги – це той двигун, який штовхає її вперед. Сімнадцять позик, які вона отримала від „Надії України” сприяли розвитку її бізнесу. Завдяки фінансовій підтримці Галина змогла придбати дві торгові точки та взяти на роботу ще двох реалізаторів. Зараз в неї приблизно 8000 доларів в товарі. Її щомісячний валовий дохід складає 2000 доларів. Галина просить про позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб відкрити п’яту торгову точку з продажу посуду та керамічних виробів. Вона планує закупити посуд, порцелянові набори за оптовими цінами для подальшої роздрібної торгівлі в новому кіоску. Галина сподівається, що розширення бізнесу допоможе їй задовольнити попит на посуд та підвищить обсяги продажів.

loans.use: To open a new vending facility

loans.name: Vartiter

texts.en:
Vartiter has a small indoor kiosk where she offers a nice selection of kitchen ware, dishes and utensils. Originally, Vartiter trained to be a journalist. She has a degree from the prestigious Shevchenko University in Kiev, which is one of the best schools in Ukraine. Like many trained Ukrainian professionals, however, Vartiter now works as a market vendor due to a lack of good paying professional jobs.

After working for a time as a leather goods specialist, Vartiter started her current business, which she has now operated for several years. Nadiya Ukraine has previously assisted her with four different loans. She has requested an additional loan of $1000 for two purposes. She needs to purchase additional inventory for her current business, and she would also like to use some money to help open a second sales kiosk where she could begin selling clothing items. She is hoping that by expanding her overall business enterprise and moving into a new area of retail she will be able to increase her income and improve her standard of living.

Вартітер – власниця невеликого кіоску, вона торгує кухонним приладдям, посудом та обладнанням. Вона отримала освіту журналіста. Вчилася в престижному вузі ім. Тараса Шевченка в Києві, а цей вуз вважається одним з найкращих в Україні. Однак, як і багато інших спеціалістів, через брак робочих місць Вартітер зараз працює на ринку продавцем. Певний час вона торгувала шкіряними виробами, потім вирішила почати власну справу. Займається цим бізнесом вже декілька років. Від „Надії України” отримала 4 позики, вчасно їх сплативши. Зараз Вартітер просить про наступну позику в 1000 доларів через декілька причин. Вона хоче закупити додатковий інвентар, щоб розширити асортимент в своєму кіоску, а також використати іншу частину коштів для того, щоб відкрити другу торгову точку з продажу одягу. Вартітер сподівається, що завдяки розширенню власного бізнесу вона зможе підвищити власні прибутки та покращити рівень життя своєї родини.

loans.use: Increase inventory and open new location

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina N. is a master of hair dressing and has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She is seeking a loan of US$850.00 from Kiva to help her expand her shop.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Vitali

texts.en:
Vitali is a young clothing merchant from Nikopol, Ukraine on the beautiful Dnepro River. He started his small business when he was in his late 20’s and gradually, though much hard work, he has been able to develop it into quite a successful enterprise.

Vitali has the qualities it takes to succeed as an entrepreneur. Goal-oriented, hard-working and punctual, he is a natural business man. Funding from “Nadiya Ukraine” has been instrumental in helping Vitali build his business. His first loan was for $500 and since that time he has benefited from nine additional loans while establishing a great credit history.

He has requested $1200 to add to his available working capital. The ability to purchase large quantities of inventory in bulk saves time and expense for merchants such as Vitali. He would like to buy a supply of men’s sportswear and men’s and women’s jean clothing that will boost his inventory before the busy summer season. Vitali appreciates the availability of funding through Nadiya Ukraine. It allows him to take advantage of good opportunities and focus on growing his business so that he is able to adequately provide for himself and his family.

Віталій – молодий підприємець, займається продажем одягу на місцевому ринку м. Нікополь. Він відкрив власну справу, коли йому було лише 20 з чимось. Віталій наполегливо працював й поступово його бізнес ставав успішним. У Віталія є усі якості та здібності, які необхідні підприємцю для успіху. Цілеспрямований, працьовитий та пунктуальний - він дуже ділова людина. Фінансова підтримка від „Надії України” сприяла розвитку бізнесу Віталія. Розмір його першої позики складав 500 доларів. З того часу він вчасно сплатив 9 позик, в нього склалася чудова кредитна історія. Віталій просить про позику в 1200 доларів, тому що хоче поповнити свій робочий капітал. Можливість оптом закупити велику партію товару дасть йому шанс зберегти час та зменшити витрати. Віталій планує купити повсякденний чоловічий та джинсовий жіночий одяг, розширити асортимент товарів напередодні літнього сезону. Він цінує доступність кредитних послуг в „Надії України”. Завдяки позикам у Віталія з’являється багато нових можливостей, він може зосередитися на рості свого бізнесу та забезпеченні власної родини.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Zachar

texts.en:
Zachar and his wife Ludmila are a husband and wife business team. Together they successfully manage a little grocery kiosk at one of the local markets in Nikopol. Both Zachar and Ludmila have higher educations but instead of directly applying their schooling, they decided to become business owners. Their family also consists of a little boy whom they love and nurture.

It has been Zachar and Ludmila’s desire to operate their business profitably and see it fully sustain their family. Today, they are seeing stability in their work and good returns. They would like to expend their grocery line in order to meet customer demand and generate additional profits. While both of them devote most of their time to their grocery kiosk, Ludmila has begun an additional business selling water filters. The couple is hopeful to see this venture take off in the future.

Through several years of partnering with “Nadiya Ukraine”, Zachar and Ludmila have proven themselves to be responsible, goal-oriented and hard-working entrepreneurs. Today, they are asking for a $1,000 loan to assist them in expanding the food items they have available in their busy grocery kiosk.

Захар з дружиною разом займаються бізнесом. В них є невеличкий кіоск з продажу харчів на одному з місцевих ринків м. Нікополь. В Захара та Людмили є вища освіта, але їм більше до душі власний бізнес. Вони виховують маленького сина. Захар та Людмила довго намагалися досягти прибутковості бізнесу, хотіли, щоб бізнес забезпечував усі потреби родини. Зараз їм вдалося досягти стабільності в торгівлі та підвищити власні доходи. На цьому етапі Захар і Людмила намагаються розширити асортимент товарів харчування, щоб задовольнити попит з боку покупців та отримати додатковий прибуток. Обидва наполегливо працюють для того, щоб досягти поставленої мети. До того ж Людмила почала займатися ще одним видом бізнесу, а саме продажем фільтрів для води. Подружжя сподівається, що цей бізнес буде не менш успішним ніж попередній. Захар та Людмила співпрацюють з „Надією України” вже декілька останніх років. За цей час вони проявили себе як відповідальні, цілеспрямовані та працьовиті підприємці. Зараз вони просять про позику в 1000 доларів для того, щоб поповнити асортимент товарів харчування в своєму кіоску.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Evgeniya

texts.en:
If you’re a woman looking for shoes, clothing or something to decorate your home or dining room, make sure to stop by Evgeniya’s little store in Nikopol, Ukraine. She offers an attractive array of reasonably priced shoes, clothing, tablecloths and souvenirs. If she doesn’t have what you’re looking for, she can help you find someone who does.

Vendors like Evgeniya form the backbone of a prosperous market economy in Ukraine. These entrepreneurs have, often with little help, been able to start and sustain small businesses which provide enough income for them to live on. For many their goal is to expand by opening new kiosks or renting larger retail space. They may never be the size of Wal-Mart but they’ve started in much the same way.

Evgeniya has requested a six month loan for $500 which will give her some additional working funds for her business. She believes that God has blessed her through the financial help of “Nadiya Ukraine”. Thank you for being part of God’s blessing to the hard-working entrepreneurs of Ukraine.

Якщо ви шукаєте взуття, одяг, посуд або необхідні матеріали для декору інтер‘єру кухні, обов’язково зайдіть до невеличкої крамнички Євгенії в м. Нікополь. В неї ви знайдете різноманітний вибір взуття, одягу, скатертин та сувенірів за помірними цінами. Навіть якщо в неї ви не знайдете те, що шукаєте, Євгенія підкаже, де знайти того, хто зможе вам допомогти. Саме такі підприємці, як Євгенія, сприяють процвітанню ринкової економіки України. Ці бізнесмени відкрили власну справу, утрималися на плаву та отримали непоганий прибуток. Багато хто з них прагне розширити власний бізнес та відкрити нові кіоски або орендувати більші приміщення. Можливо, вони ніколи не досягнуть розмірів великих торгівельних центрів , але ж усі починають з малого. Євгенія просить про позику в 500 доларів строком на 6 місяців, бо сподівається отримати додаткові кошти на розвиток власного бізнесу. Вона переконана, що Бог благословив її завдяки фінансовій підтримці від „Надії України”. Євгенія дякує вам за те, що ви стали частиною Божого благословення в житті старанних підприємців в Україні.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Abla

texts.en: Abla has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She cooks palm kennel oil and sells it in gallons to her clients. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Yuliya

texts.en:
Yuliya is married with an 18-year-old son. She has been a market vendor for many years and has gained rich experience in the business of selling women’s outerwear.

Yuliya has demonstrated consistency and integrity in working with “Nadiya Ukraine”. She has had no loan defaults since she took her first loan in 2003. Currently, Yuliya has about $2,000 of working capital. She re-stocks her inventory twice a month, buying from wholesalers, which helps to considerably reduce her transportation costs. Her monthly gross revenue amounts to $2,400, and her net profit is about $700.

Yuliya is requesting a loan for $800 to increase her working capital and re-supply her inventory before the spring season. She is planning to purchase an assortment of women’s clothing at wholesale prices for further retail sale. Yuliya believes that this loan will help boost her economic activity and allow her to generate more profits. It will not only help her grow her business, but will also provide better a quality of life for her and her family.

Юлія – одружена, в неї є 18-річний син. Вона торгує на ринку вже на протязі багатьох років. За цей період вона здобула багатий досвід в торгівлі жіночим верхнім одягом. В роботі з „Надією України” Юлія проявила себе як дуже послідовна та порядна людина. В неї не було жодного прострочення з того часу, як вона отримала свою першу позику в організації ще в 2003 році. Зараз в Юлії є приблизно 2000 доларів робочого капіталу. Вона робить закупки двічі на місяць на оптових базах, що допомагає їй значно знизити транспортні витрати. Її щомісячний валовий дохід складає приблизно 2400 доларів, чистий прибуток становить 700 доларів. Юлія просить про позику в 800 доларів для того, щоб збільшити власний робочий капітал та поповнити запас товарів напередодні весняного сезону. Вона планує закупити асортимент жіночого одягу за оптовими цінами для подальшої роздрібної торгівлі. Юлія вважає, що позика сприятиме економічному зростанню її бізнесу та допоможе отримати додатковий прибуток. Фінансова допомога не тільки сприятиме росту торгівлі Юлії, але й забезпечить якісно краще життя для її родини.

loans.use: To increase on stock

loans.name: Ladger

texts.en: Ladger has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She cooks palm kernel oil and sells to customers in drums and gallons. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

She is seeking a loan of US$900.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Altagracia

texts.en:
Altagracia O. supports her four daughters and one son by selling new clothing and shoes in her community. Most of her profit comes from selling dress shoes and shirts but her client base is larger because she also sells miscellaneous items that appeal to a broader demographic - including cosmetics, accessories, toys and personal care products.

This $400 loan will finance the expansion of her business - specifically purchasing more new clothing and shoes to increase sales. Plus, she will be able to afford better quality garments that can sell for a higher profit margin, which will give her more money to invest in savings and the needs of her children, on top of putting money back into her business.


Altagracia is one of Esperanza's special individual borrowers. She is still part of her Bank of Hope, which her group has named 'La Simpatía', but because of the success and size of her business, as well as her payment of previous loans, she is now eligible for larger, individual loan sizes.

loans.use: Purchase clothing and shoes

She cooks palm oil and sells it to market women for retail. She is seeking a loan of US$800.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

She sells smoked dry fish in the market. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Miltha

texts.en:
Miltha C. already has a small general store near her home in San Pedro de Macoris where she lives with her son and two daughters. To improve the living conditions of her family, she is starting a second business, selling clothing out of her general store as well. This loan will finance the seed money necessary to buy the clothing as well as restock her inventory of food staples and household items that she is currently selling with great success.

NOTE: Miltha is a member of an Esperanza solidarity group. She and her business represent four other micro-entrepreneurs who are members of the same solidarity group who will all receive a share of this $750 loan to develop their respective businesses. Miltha and the other members are accountable to each other for making loan repayments together.

loans.use: Purchase food staples and household items for general store; purchase apparel for clothing store

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana lives in Nkurankan, Ghana and has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She sells onions at the market. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her sales.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience A. has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She lives in a big market area where she sells onions. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her sales.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ma Esther

texts.en:
Mrs. Ma Esther S. has sold used clothing and sneakers for the past year. "It's been very difficult to save money to purchase the clothing and shoes. This business is our the only source of income for my family. I would like to buy more Spring and Summer clothes since I have winter clothes which I won't sell at this time of year. I request $1,000 to invest in my business."

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Ma Esther S. tiene 1 año con su venta de ropa de segunda y tenis. “Me ha sido muy difícil juntar un poco de dinero para comprar la ropa y los tenis, este negocio es la única fuente de ingresos que tenemos mi esposo y mis hijos quisiera comprar un poco más de ropa de temporada de Primavera-Verano ya que tengo ropa de tiempo de frío que ya no voy a vender en esta época del año”. Solicito 1,000.00 dlls para invertirle a mi negocio.

loans.use: Purchase Spring and Summer clothes

loans.name: Estani

texts.en:
Estani has paid off her first loan and is requesting a second loan to expand her growing business. Estani supports two daughters and a son thanks to the income of her clothing store, which she operates out of their home. She will also use this loan to purchase various household products that patrons of her clothing store are in the market for as well.

NOTE: Estani is one of four micro-entrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, which have all gone through Esperanza's business training courses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their shares of this $750 loan together. If a member is unable to pay in full on time, the group is responsible for making up the deficit before a payment can be made. Investors in this loan will receive an update on Estani's situation as well as that of the entire group.

loans.use: Invest in dresses, blouses and miscellaneous household items

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort M. has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She cooks palm oil and kenkey (a local meal) that she sells. She is seeking a loan of US$800.00 from Kiva to help her expand her production.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She sells onions at the market. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva to help her expand her sales.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa sells hats, shoes and clothes to adolescents in her neighborhood. She has three of her own, two girls and one boy, whom she raises and puts through school with the income generated by her business. Teresa has paid off her first loan from Esperanza, which gave her the opportunity to start her own business. This loan will allow her to replenish her inventory and expand the types of products she can sell.

OTE: Teresa is a member of an Esperanza solidarity group, which means this $750 will go to finance her business as well as four other micro-entrepreneurs in her community, whom Teresa has gone through training with and they will make each loan repayment together. You will receive journals covering Teresa's progress and that of her fellow group members.

loans.use: Invest in hats, shoes, t-shirts, skirts and pants for her clothing store inventory

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose D. has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She sells rice, groundnut (in tins of olonka) and cooking ingredients at the market. She is seeking a loan of US$700.00 from Kiva.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply their shop at school.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes lives in Nkurankan, Ghana and has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She cooks kenkey and fried fish (a local meal) and sells it to school children in her town. She is seeking a loan of $700.00 from Kiva to help her cook enough for sale.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea Dolvil is raising her three young daughters and started cooking and selling food to pay expenses and be able to save. She sells bread and particularly a popular indigenous Dominican dish called 'casabe' made of boiled yucca or cassava roots. She sells her food in her community in public places like parks or local schools during lunchtime. This loan will go towards buying more ingredients to prepare and cook her meals along with materials to store, cook and carry her food.

NOTE: Andrea is a leader of her solidarity group, which the members call 'Unión de la Caridad'. She represents four other micro-entrepreneurs, who will each receive an equal $150 share of this $750 loan to invest in their respective businesses.

loans.use: Buy cooking oil, pots, bread-making ingredients and yucca

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve their rice fields by building a dike to control the flooding.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta opened a small store out of her home with the first loan she received from Esperanza. She sells miscellaneous personal care products and kitchen ware. This loan will allow her to start selling children's clothing for which there is a good market in her semi-rural neighbourhood outside the capital city of the San Pedro de Macoris province.

NOTE: Violeta belongs to a Bank of Hope which is a community of five micro-entrepreneurs who receive shares of a communal loan to expand their businesses. Each member of Violeta's group has already received and paid back a loan, demonstrating responsibility and business aptitude. This $750 loan will fund these businesses to expand their new business to increase capital, investment opportunities and savings.

loans.use: Purchase new children's clothing

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She owns a shop where she sells provisions and other items. She is seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to help her expand her sales.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.en:
Gerardo es un hombre emprendedor y muy responsable, el tiene 36 años de edad, es casado y tiene dos hijos de 11 y 6 años. Él empezó con su negocio de venta de calzado hace cinco años, era una época muy difícil porque no tenía trabajo y aunque su esposa estaba empleada, con su salario no podía solventar todos los gastos del hogar, así fue como se inició en el negocio con una inversión muy pequeña y poco a poco sus ventas se han incrementado al igual que su negocio.

Ahora Gerardo necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 650 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para poder ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad y permanecer en su preferencia, él ofrece regresar esta cantidad en un lapso de 5 a 10 meses. En tus manos está el bienestar de esta familia, decídete a apoyarlos, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu ayuda.

Translated to English by Nuria Ruiz

Gerardo is a responsible entrepreneur, he is 36 years old, married and has two kids of 11 and 6. He started his shoe selling business 5 years ago. It was a hard time for him cause he was unemployed and although his wife was working at the time, her salary was not enough to provide for the family. He started with a very small investment but little by little his business has grown.

Gerardo is asking for a $650 loan. He is planning to use the money to buy more goods for his business so he can better serve his clients. He'll repay the loan in a 5 to 10 month interval. Gerardo and his family really appreciate your help.

loans.use: Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She sells agricultural produce such as cassava and plantain. She is seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to help her expand her sales.
